Ottawa, February 4, 1914.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo stating that on account of illness Sister Mary of the Holy Rosary, teacher of the Pointe Blue School, has retired from teaching and that Sister Marie Antoinette has taken her place.

In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of the appointment of Sister Marie Antoinette as teacher of this school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.
Pointe Bleue, Oct.6,1914.

The Secretary,

Dept. of I.A.,

Ottawa.

Sir,-

I attach herewith the quarterly report of the Pointe Bleue school with the necessary requisition for the payment of the salaries of the teachers.

The Assistant Mistress, Sr.St.Raphael, is obliged to give up teaching for some months on account of her health. The Superior General of the Community of the Sisters of Good Counsel tells me that she will be replaced by Sr.St. Louis, another excellent teacher of that Community.

Sr.St.Raphael, who is a very delicate person, appears to be threatened with consumption. She has been suffering for some weeks from a severe cough.

I have,&c.,

A.Tessier,

I.A.
Pointe Blene, 6 octobre 1914.

Monsieur,

Ci-joint le rapport trimestriel relatif à l'école de Pointe Blene avec la réquisition nécessaire pour le paiement du salaire des instituteurs.

La maîtresse assistante, Sr. St. Raphael, est obligée d'abandonner pour quelques mois l'enseignement pour cause de santé. La supérieure générale de la Communauté des Soeurs du Bon Conseil me dit qu'elle sera remplacée par Sr. St. Louis, une autre excellente institutrice de cette communauté.

Sr. St. Raphael qui était une femme très-faible souffre encore de convalescence. Elle souffre depuis quelques semaines d'une forte toux.

J'ai l'honneur d'être,

Monsieur,

Votre obéissant serviteur,

A. Tessier,
Agent des dommages.
Ottawa October 17th, 1914.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant in which you state that Sister St. Raphael is obliged to give up teaching on account of ill-health.

The Department regrets very much to learn of Sister St. Raphael's illness and trusts that her health will improve.

The appointment of Sister St. Louis is approved.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.
REPORT OF INSPECTOR J.F. BOILY ON THE GIFT BLUE BAY SCHOOL.

On June 21, last, I had the honour to visit the Indians' school at Pointe Bleue and make a fairly thorough examination of the 90 pupils present.

Permit me to remark that this splendid attendance was due to the fact that most of the Indians had returned from the woods and for some days had been sending their children to school.

It is this way every year, that is to say, that a large number of little Indians go to school only ten or fifteen days a year. Why would the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa not establish classes during the holidays for these young Indians? I humbly submit this idea to you and I trust that the Department at Ottawa will take it into consideration.

Report dated, July 5th, 1915.
Ottawa, August 5, 1915.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Boily in his recent report on the Pointe Bleue School states that every year a large number of little Indians go to school only ten or fifteen days a year and suggests that the Department establish classes during the holidays for these young Indians.

The Indian Day School Regulations provide that "where in the interest of the school work such action may be desirable, the holidays allowed during the summer (two months) may, upon the recommendation of the local Agent, be taken at some other time of the year; but no change is to be made without the express approval of the Department."

It is too late in the season now to make a change in the holidays for this school this year, but next year, if it is considered advisable, the school may be kept open during the summer and the holidays taken at some other time. You should bring the matter to the attention of the Department early next summer.

Your obedient servant,

S. STEWART

A. Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Pointe-Blanche, 3 octobre 1916.

À la Secrétairie,
Dépôt des affaires des Sauvages,
Ottawa,

Monsieur,

Je regrette de vous dire que bien Marie-Antoinette, institutrice à l'école de Pointe-Blanche, est partie de prendre un repos de quelques mois dans l'intérêt de sa santé. Pour le mois de septembre il lui a fallu être aidé par l'une de ses compatriotes de la même Communauté, donc Mme Vincent de Paul, qui continue à la remplacer ici si le Département n'y voit aucune objection.

Cette institutrice possède un diplôme avec en outre une expérience de quelques années dans l'enseignement. Une de l'Inspection des Écoles Boly à qui j'ai téléphoné à son sujet me dit que c'est l'une des meilleures institutrices de son district. Elle enseignait l'an dernier et depuis quelques années à Hermannville, Lac du Fou, et son selle a été l'une de celles où le progrès des élèves a été le plus marquant.

D'autre part, j'ai le plaisir de vous informer ainsi que trois des anciennes élèves inscrites de l'école de Pointe-Blanche, possédant leurs diplômes d'institutrices obtenus devant le Bureau des examinateurs de la Province, ont été engagées par les municipalités suivantes chez les blancs pour faire la classe dans le cours de la prochaine année. Melle Anna Robertson et Kate Simpson ont la charge d'une école chacune dans la paroisse de St. Pépin et Melle Alice Cleary est chargée de l'école modèle de St. Felicien. Toutes trois reçoivent d'excellents salaires. Le fait doit être de nature à satisfaire votre Département sur le résultat obtenu jusqu'ici par votre école des Sauvages.

Grâce aux efforts constants de votre Dépôt
Département en ce qui se rapporte à l'éducation indienne, notre humble école des sauvages, fournit aujourd'hui à la population blanche un service de très utiles, des institutions capables et éduquées.

C'est un fait, pour ainsi dire évident, mais qui n'en est pas moins accompli : des écoles pour les blancs !

Ci-joint aussi mon rapport annuel pour septembre concernant l'école des sauvages de Pointe-Blanche.

Jeudi, 1er octobre de l'année 1875,

M. le ministre,

A. Tessier,

Agent des sauvages.
Pointe Bleue, Oct. 3, 1916.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Sir,

I regret to inform you that Sister Marie Antoinette, teacher of the Pointe Bleue school, is forced to take a rest of some months on account of her health. For the month of September she had to be assisted by one of her sister nuns of the same community, Sister St. Vincent de Paul, who will continue to take her place here if the Department has no objection.

This teacher has diplomas and also an experience of fourteen years in teaching. Mr. Boily, Inspector of Schools, to whom I telephoned on the subject, tells me that she is one of the best teachers of his district. She was teaching last year and for some years past at Normandin, Lake St. John, and her school was one of those in which the progress of the pupils has been most marked.

On the other hand, I have the pleasure of telling you that three of the former Indian pupils of the Pointe Bleue school, holding diplomas as teachers obtained from the Provincial Board of Examiners, have been engaged by some school municipalities among the white people to teach school during the course of the present year. Misses Anna Robertson and Kate Simpson are each in charge of a school in the parish of St. Prime, and Miss Alice Cleary is in charge of the model school of St. Felicien. All three are receiving excellent salaries. This fact ought to be of a nature to satisfy your Department as to the results obtained up to the present time by our Indian school.

Thanks to the constant efforts of your Department in regard to Indian education, our humble Indian school supplies today to the white population of the county of Lake St. John some capable and devoted teachers.

It is an astonishing fact, so to speak, but none the less it is a fact: some Indian women are educating white people!

I attach also my monthly report for September in regard to the Indian school at Pointe Bleue.

I have, &c.,

A. Tessier,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 12, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant informing the Department that Sister Marie Antoinette, teacher of the Pointe Bleue School, is forced to take a rest of some months on account of her health, and that Sister St. Vincent de Paul will take her place.

In reply I beg to say that the Department regrets to learn that Sister Marie Antoinette is not in good health. The appointment of Sister St. Vincent de Paul to take her place is approved.

The Department is very pleased to learn that three former pupils of this school have been engaged to teach in white schools during the present year.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

In connection with my memorandums of the 13th and 16th instant regarding increases in the salaries to the teachers of the Restigouche Indian Day School and showing the salaries received by the teachers at Lorette and Pointe Bleue I beg to again draw your attention to the amount allowed for salaries to the teachers at the last named schools and would also draw attention to the salaries paid to the teachers at the Bersimis School.

At Lorette the principal and assistant each receive $250.00 per annum and the bonus, or a combined salary and bonus of $400.00.

At Pointe Bleue the principal is paid $300.00 per annum and the assistant $250.00. They also each receive the bonus of $150.00, thus making the amount received by the principal $450.00 and the assistant $400.00.

At Bersimis the teachers are paid $275.00 each and they also receive the bonus of $150.00, a combined salary and bonus of $425.00.

The salaries of the two teachers at Restigouche have recently been increased and they receive, from the first of October, last, salaries as follows, the principal $350.00 and the assistant $350.00.

I would recommend that the salaries to be paid to the teachers at the Lorette, Pointe Bleue and Bersimis Schools be increased to the same amount as at Restigouche, as the teachers at these schools have a large attendance and perform their duties and they are giving satisfaction in their work. At Restigouche there was an enrolment of 87 pupils.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

In connection with my memorandums of the 13th and 16th instant regarding increases in the salaries to the teachers of the Restigouche Indian Day School and showing the salaries received by the teachers at Lorette and Pointe Bleue I beg to again draw your attention to the amount allowed for salaries to the teachers at the last named schools and would also draw attention to the salaries paid to the teachers at the Bersimis School.

At Lorette the principal and assistant each receive $250.00 per annum and the bonus, or a combined salary and bonus of $400.00.

At Pointe Bleue the principal is paid $300.00 per annum and the assistant $250.00. They also each receive the bonus of $150.00, thus making the amount received by the principal $450.00 and the assistant $400.00.

At Bersimis the teachers are paid $275.00 each and they also receive the bonus of $150.00, a combined salary and bonus of $425.00.

The salaries of the two teachers at Restigouche have recently been increased and they receive, from the first of October, last, salaries as follows; the principal $350.00 and the assistant $350.00.

I would recommend that the salaries of the teachers at the Lorette, Pointe Bleue and Bersimis Schools be increased to the same amount as at Restigouche, as the teachers at these schools have a large attendance and perform their duties and they are giving satisfaction in their work. At Restigouche there was an enrolment of 87 pupils.
of about 50; at Lorette the enrolment is 68 pupils and the average attendance 60; at Pointe Bleue the enrolment is 85 with an average attendance of 62 and at Bersimis the enrolment during six months of year is about 96 and for the September quarter, last, the average attendance was 92. During the winter the Indians are away hunting and the enrolment at the Bersimis School is about 25, with an average of 21.

If my recommendation is approved, the salary of the principal of Lorette should be increased by $200.00 and the assistant by $100.00; at Pointe Bleue the salary of the principal should be increased by $150.00 and the assistant by $100.00 and at Bersimis the salary of the principal should be increased by $175.00 and the assistant by $75.00. By allowing these increases the salaries at these three schools will be the same as paid the teachers at Restigouche. There is practically the same amount of work to be done at all these schools and the teachers have the same qualifications. If these increases are approved by you they should date from the first of October, last, the beginning of the present quarter.
Ottawa, November 24, 1920.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that it has been decided to increase the salaries of the teachers at the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School from the first of October, last. At present the principal is paid $300.00 per annum and the assistant $250.00. From the above date these salaries will be increased as follows:- the principal will be paid at the rate of $450.00 per annum and the assistant at the rate of $350.00 per annum. This is an increase of $150.00 in the salary of the principal and of $100.00 in the salary of the assistant. This increase is made to equalise the salaries paid the teaching sisters in the Indian day schools in the Province of Quebec.

I have to request that you will be good enough to inform the teachers of the above increase allowed them from the first of October, last. You should see that their quarterly returns are forwarded promptly at the end of each quarter, in order that payment of salary can be made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.
Sir,

Voici le rapport des institutions de l'école des sauvages de Pointe-Blanche avec une réquisition pour un salaire.

Le nombre d'élèves qui ont fréquenté l'école en septembre n'a pas été aussi grand qu'espéré et nous avons pu voir que le nombre d'enfants suffisant de la catégorie est de cette école.

Maintenant que cette épidémie est passée le nombre d'enfants fréquentant l'école est redevenu normal et atteint près de soixante et quelque.

Pointe-Blanche, 1922.

M. le Secrétaire,
Agent des Affaires des Sauvages,
Ottawa,

Monseigneur,

Je joins le rapport de l'institution de l'école des sauvages de Pointe-Blanche pour la dernière année.

Dans le cours de la année de 1921, un certain nombre d'élèves ont été admis dans l'établissement et ont été enseignés par les soins du Conseil. Cette dernière institution a fait la classe des sauvages à l'éducation pendant plusieurs années, de sorte qu'elle a toute l'expérience nécessaire. Elle a aussi une expérience en matière de la formation de jeunes.

Je me tiens à votre disposition,

Monseigneur,

Votre obéissant serviteur,

[Signature]

Agent des Sauvages
Pointe Bleue, January 1st, 1922.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA - Ont.

Dear Sir,-

Enclosed herewith you will find the report of the lady teachers of the Indian School at Pointe Bleue for the last quarter.

Sister St. Louis, on the advice of her doctor, being forced to take a long rest in the interest of her health, was temporarily replaced by Sister Marie du Carmel. The latter has taught to Indians at Bersimis for several years, so that she has all the necessary experience. She also has her diploma from the Board of Examiners of Quebec.

Yours........etc.,
(SGD) Armand Tessier,
Indian Agent.
OTTAWA, January 12th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the last instant, enclosing the December quarter return of the teacher of the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School and stating that, owing to the illness of Sister St. Louis, Sister Marie du Carmel, a former teacher, was placed temporarily in charge.

In reply I beg to say that this arrangement for the carrying on of the work during the illness of Sister St. Louis is approved.

Sister Marie du Carmel will be allowed the same salary as was paid Sister St. Louis.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

A. Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.
Maison-Mère des Soeurs de N.-D. du Bon-Conseil,
Chicoutimi, 22 avril 1927.

Monsieur le Secrétaire
Ministère des Affaires des Sauvages
Ottawa

Monsieur le Secrétaire,

C'est avec confiance que je vous adresse la requête suivante : d'accorder à nos Soeurs institutrices à l'école de la Réserve (Pointe-Bleue) leurs deux mois de vacances habituelles.

Voici les raisons qui motivent ma demande :
Vous n'avez pas oublié qu'en janvier dernier, la maison d'école étant absolument inhabitable, Monsieur Tessier, agent de la Réserve, obtenait l'autorisation de fermer les classes pendant les deux mois les plus rigoureux ; c'est ce que l'on comprit tout de suite.

Les classes ont été reprises dès le début de mars et, comme par le passé, nos Soeurs ne ménagent ni leurs fatigues, ni leurs peines pour le bien de ces pauvres enfants et même pour le bien de toutes les familles en général tant indiennes que métis.

Cependant, malgré leur zèle, les vacances
d'été leur sont pour ainsi dire indispensables à la Maison-Mère. C'est pourquoi, Monsieur le Secrétaire, je n'hésite pas à solliciter de votre influente bienveillance l'obtention de cette faveur pour nos deux Sœurs institutrices, me souvenant que le Département a accordé même une année presqu'entièrée à nos Sœurs lors de la reconstruction du Couvent de Bersimis, et cela nonobstant les deux mois de vacances ordinaires.

J'ose donc espérer une réponse favorable, d'autant plus que Monsieur Tessier est tout à fait bien disposé à ce sujet et juge comme nous que ces deux mois seraient à peu près nuls pour les classes.

Daignez agréer, Monsieur le Secrétaire l'hommage de mes respectueux sentiments et me croire en N.-S.

Votre très humble

[Signature]

Votre très humble
Translation.

Convent of N.D. du Bon-Conseil,
Chicoutimi, April 22, 1927.

The Secretary,

Sir,

It is with confidence that I am addressing you this request; that is to grant our Sister teachers of the Point Bleue reserve their usual two months' holidays.

Here are the reasons for this request; you have not forgotten that during January last the school house was uninhabitable. Mr. Tessier, Indian Agent, was authorized to close the school during the two coldest months; this was once understood.

The classes were re-opened in the beginning of March and as in the past our Sisters do not spare their fatigue, nor their work for the good of these poor children and even for the welfare of the Indian families as well as the half-breeds.

However, taking account of their kindness, the summer holidays are absolutely necessary at the Mother House. That is why, sir, I do not hesitate to ask you to kindly use your influence to obtain this favour for our teaching Sisters. As I remember that you Department was kind enough to grant nearly a full year to our Sisters when the Convent at Bersimis was re-built besides the two annual months of holidays.

I there hope that you will send us a favourable reply as Mr. Tessier is quite agreeable and believes that these two months would be absolutely useless as far as the school work is concerned.

Yours etc.,

Sister St. Elzear.

Superior General.
Ottawa, April 30th, 1927.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, in which you request that permission be granted to the Rev. Sisters, teachers of the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School, to take the usual summer holidays during the months of July and August, next.

In reply I beg to say that, besides the period already allowed, viz. January and February, last, the Department will approve of the school being closed for the regular summer holidays for the months above mentioned, viz. July and August. Salaries will be allowed in full for the time the school was closed during January and February, and cheques in payment to the teachers for the quarter ended March 31st, last, are being sent.

We are informing Mr. Agent Tessier of the permission granted to close the school for the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Sister St. Elzear,
Superior General,
Convent of M.D. du Bon-Conseil,
Chicoutimi, P.Q.
Ottawa, April 30th, 1927.

Sir:

At the request of the Superior General of the Convent of N. D. du Bon-Conseil, the Department is granting the teachers of the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School permission to close the school for the coming summer holidays in July and August, next. As you are aware, permission was granted to have this school closed during January and February, last, and we are allowing full salary for these months. Cheques in full payment for the March quarter salary are being sent the teachers. We are informing the Superior General of the above Convent of the permission granted to close this school for the regular summer holiday period.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, P.Q.
Maison-Mère des Soeurs de N.-D. du Bon-Conseil,
Chicoutimi, 26 mai 1927.

Monsieur le Secrétaire
du Département des affaires indiennes
Ottawa

Monsieur le Secrétaire,

Veuillez agréer nos meilleurs remerciements pour la bienveillance avec laquelle vous avez accueilli notre demande au sujet des prochaines vacances pour nos Soeurs institutrices à la Pointe-Bleue, Lac St-Jean. Croyez que nous vous en sommes sincèrement reconnaissantes.

Nous espérons que le Département ne tardera pas plus longtemps la construction de la nouvelle école à la Réserve. La maison actuelle n'est certainement plus habitable à tous les points de vue, et les classes, qui nécessairement ont dû être interrompues au cours de la présente année, ne pourraient être reprises dans les mêmes conditions en septembre prochain.

Nous osons donc compter sur la bonne considération du Gouvernement en cette nécessité absolue, afin de pouvoir continuer à faire tout le bien à ces pauvres gens qui profitent avantageusement, pour la plupart d'ailleurs, de ce qu'on fait pour eux.

Je demeure respectueusement, Monsieur le Secrétaire,

Votre bien humble en N.-S.

[Signature]

In reply I beg to say that the change of teachers at this school is noted.

Aasst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. Tessier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, P.Q.
Sir,

Please find herewith the teachers' quarterly report for quarter ending 31st of March.

Upon Dr. Piccardi's request, and by a telegram dated March 17th, the Department authorized the closing of the school during the epidemic of measles. We have a few cases yet, but hope that in a few days the epidemic will have come to an end, and that we will be allowed to reopen the school soon.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

POINTE BLEUE DAY SCHOOL
De notre Maman-Mère,
Chicoutimi, 8 février 1932

M. A. De la Bérardière,
Sainte-Blanche.

Monsieur,

Pour faire suite à votre demande, je dois vous dire que j'ai pu être assuré une institution parlant la langue patoisée, pour les mois de juillet et août. J'interrogerais donc dans l'action et il est impossible d'agir.

Sir:

Referring to resolution of the Pointe Bleue Band of the 13th ultimo requesting that a summer school be conducted at Pointe Bleue during the months of July and August, next, for the benefit of the children of the Indian hunters who return from the bush at that time, I have to say that the Department will approve of a summer school being conducted during the above named months, and would allow the teacher salary at the rate of $60 per month. Depuis vingt-six ans que l'école de la Pointe Bleue est dirigée par les religieuses de M.O. du Bon Conseil.

Durant tout ce temps des soeurs ont donné aux enfants indiens des leçons d'instruction et d'éducation. Elles ont changé de local pour la classe deux fois; la première maison d'école n'était plus qu'une vieille maison en ruine, l'autre construite il y a une dizaine d'années, pour deux classes, plus moderne et plus solide mais cependant pas assez chaude en hiver malgré tout le bois qu'on apporte à chauffer, bar- rin au fait-disant de ce côté là. Fumais à air chaud qui ne chauffe habituellement qu'une classe; dans l'autre les élèves plus petits et plus nombreux y souffrent beaucoup du froid obligés qu'ils sont parfois de garder tous leurs habits. Un petit poêle dans cette classe y ferait un grand bien.

Autre chose, sans avoir eu remarqué sur le rapport de septembre que les élèves sont trop nombreux pour deux classes, 344 591 surtout en cette dernière, il est in...
pour que de suffire à la tâche et encore plus difficile d'y faire progresser les élèves. Tous ces élèves ont sept ans et révolus. Voici donc votre Marie du Carmel, directrice de la classe et institutrice des Indiens à Béthanie et à la Pointe-Blanche depuis vingt ans. Gentlemen,

For 26 years the school at Pointe Bleue has been under the care of the Sisters of Notre-Dame du Bon Conseil.

During all this time two sisters have taught the Indian children of both sexes. The location of their school has changed on two occasions: the first school house was an old building in ruins; the next one, built about 10 years ago and containing two classrooms, is more modern and in better condition. However, it is not warm enough in winter, in spite of all the care given to its heating. The hot air furnace gives the necessary heat to one room only; in the other, the pupils, who are younger and more numerous, suffer a great deal from the cold and are often obliged to retain their over-clothing. A small stove in this classroom would be a decided improvement.

You have probably noticed, by the September report, that the pupils are very numerous, too numerous, in fact, for the two classrooms, in one of which there are 34 and in the other 59. It is almost impossible, especially in the latter classroom, to give the proper instruction. The ages of the pupils vary from 7 to 15. We cannot refuse any of them and there are still about 15 awaiting their seventh birthday in the course of the year to begin attending school. What shall we do?

The undersigned, Sr. Marie du Carmel, has been for 20 years directing and teaching in the Indian school at Betsiamits and Pointe Bleue. I think the Department of Indian Affairs, which has always so graciously granted our requests, probably because they have not been frequent, will not refuse to grant to the Reverend Father, the priest, a small sum of about $100.00 which would provide a small school house to be opened by him at a short distance from ours, and which would remain under his control. This would prove a boon to the children who live a couple of miles away from our school and would remedy the over-crowding to a certain extent.

Mr. Fabien, translator of the Department of Indian Affairs, who accompanied the English-speaking inspector, promised to look after our request, but death removed him too soon. I hope that those who replace him will not be less kind and that the small amount that we ask for will not meet any objection.

I rely on your kindness and thank you in advance.

(Signed) Sr. Marie du Carmel, Pointe Bleue.

Monsieur,

Il y a environ quinze jours, la Révérende Sœur Marie du Carmel, directrice des Études à notre école de Pointe Bleue, vous a écrit au sujet du grand nombre d'élèves, spécialement dans sa classe.

Il y a plus de 10 ans que nous demandons au Département la construction d'une école dans le rang C, distant de 2 milles de l'école du village.

En 1930, la veille des élections fédérales, on nous l'avait promis même des inspecteurs sont venus choisir le terrain. Le gouvernement King est tombé et l'école aussi.

À diverses reprises, j'ai demandé moi-même et on m'a toujours répondu qu'il n'y avait pas de subsides votés à cette fin.

Quand M. Robertson, inspecteur des Réserves est venu, cette année, je lui ai fait la même demande et il nous a répondu qu'il en parlerait encore au Département, parce qu'il croyait la chose nécessaire.

M. de la Boissière, agent des Indiens, a fait les mêmes demandes, ainsi que le Conseil.

Toujours la même réponse.

Serait-ce donc que l'on veut nous lasser et espère-t-on que nous allons abandonner ce projet? Que l'on se le dise. Nous ne lâcherons pas.

Et comme cette année, il est trop tard pour entreprendre cette école, je vous demande de nouveau ceci:

1. Un octroi de $0.50 par mois par enfant, qu'il appartienne à la tribu ou non et qu'il soit âgé de 7 ans à 15 ans, demeurant en dehors du village et cela depuis le 1 novembre jusqu'au 24 juin.

2. La nomination par moi-même de institutrices non diplômées, mais anciennes institutrices, à cette fin.

3. La réponse en français à toutes nos lettres.

J'espère, Monsieur, que l'on ne se contentera pas de prendre ces demandes seulement en sérieuse considération, mais qu'on agira immédiatement.

Je demeure, Monsieur, votre tout dévoué.

Dear Sir,

I fully appreciate that the Department has to reply to a very large number of requests, but it seems to me that $100.00 is merely a drop in a bucket of water. I cannot think that you really intend refusing my request and this explains that once again I should come to you. Twenty years ago, we had two classes. Since then, the population has considerably increased and we still have only two classes. Our present classrooms are spacious, but, nevertheless, we cannot pile in the pupils who are much too numerous for accommodation. Besides, another point to be considered is the great distance those children have to travel to come to school. They have to walk between two and two and a half miles in either direction. Mr. de la Boissière, with whom I discussed my present request, is of the opinion that it should have been made long ago and that it is highly opportune and even absolutely necessary. Our pupils are intelligent and studious, the attendance is good, but owing to the great distance, several girls cannot come on account of the cold weather in winter. I do hope, gentlemen, that I shall receive a favorable answer from you some time next week, and that by November our children shall have new classrooms closer to their homes. I am enclosing a letter from the parish priest. In submitting my report for September I asked for 12 dozen of Dominion B copybooks which I have not yet received.

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir,

About 10 days ago, Sister Marie du Carmel, Dean of Studies of our Pointe Bleue school, wrote to you in connection with a large number of pupils, particularly in her classroom.

She was requesting a grant of $100, in order to decentralize some pupils and to send them to maternal schools under my control. You replied to her that no monies had been voted for that purpose.

For more than 10 years we have asked the Department to build a school in Range C, two miles from the village school. In 1930, on the eve of the federal election, the construction of a school had been promised and inspectors had come to select the land. The King Government was defeated and the school was not built.

On several occasions I have requested the construction of such a school, but each time I was informed that there was no money available. When Mr. Robertson, inspector of Reserves, visited us this year I renewed my request. He told me at the time that he would take the matter up with the Department since he believed such a school to be urgently needed.

Mr. De la Boissière, Indian Agent, and the Indian Council have made the same request and received the same answer. Is the purpose of this oft repeated excuse to make us cease asking for the construction of a school? Let it be known now that we will not capitulate. Since it is too late this year to begin such construction I make the following requests:

1. That a grant of 30 cents be made for each pupil whether he is belonging to the tribe or not, between the age of 7 to 15, living outside the village, and this during the period of November 1 to June 24.
2. The appoint by myself of teachers not holding the diploma, but former teachers here, for that purpose.

3. Replies in French to all our letters.

I trust, Sir, that our request will not only be taken into consideration but that immediate action will be taken.

Yours very truly,

(Signed) J. Décarie, C.M.I.,
pastor.

Gentlemen,

I am very sorry to hear that only such a small amount is not available from the Department of Indian Affairs. Memorandum:

1. Mr. Hoey,
2. Mr. Christianson

Re: Pointe Bleue Agency

While on my general inspection at the above Agency, the matter of education was brought to my attention, and after listening to certain suggestions, I thought best to submit the same to you on a special memorandum.

We find on this Reserve a certain number of children who have never been to, and will not have any opportunity to attend school, as their families spend most of their time in the woods, and are only on the Reserve for about three months during the summer.

Far from me is the idea of high education among the Indians in general, but no education at all, wherever it is possible to give it, is no better. We find in some places the regular ten month September - June year; in other bands - three month summer schools, for the benefit of young Indians who follow their families in the woods; but at Pointe Bleue, the children coming from the woods are never given an opportunity to attend school during their stay at the lake.

The following arrangement was discussed with the Missionary, Father Decarie, Agent de la Boisserie and the Sisters, and appears to meet local conditions:

1. School year for Grades 3 - 4 - 5 & 6, October 1st - April 30th (7 months).
2. Juniors - June, July and August (3 months) including children from families in the woods, Juniors and others.
3. May and September - teachers' holidays.
4. During May, children could help at Spring's work. During September, children could help at crops; thus providing them with farming and gardening.

The above arrangement would provide for ten months schooling, and the proposed division of the ten months would benefit all of the children, instead of the present conditions which do not allow any of the families in the woods to give their children the least schooling. The attendance to school is also a good training for discipline and good manners.

There are but few left of the experienced canoe makers of old - snowshoe making will also be a thing of the past, unless steps are taken to train the young men, showing
some ability, to make canoes and snowshoes.

There is already a fair start in agriculture, and I only hope that the same will be given close attention and due consideration. Lack of trapping in past few years has been instrumental in the increased interest in farming; let us keep it up, and encourage any move towards more and better farming, so that more will be kept off the relief list and become self-supporting.

It is hoped that you will understand that the above suggestions are made only in view of the improvement in the conditions of these Indians. The proposal changes in school year are, in my opinion, to benefit all the Indian children of school age, whether they remain on the Reserve the year around, or whether they only come to spend three summer months in the year.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Quebec Inspectorate.
Ottawa,
April 27, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Monsieur,

J'ai visité ce jour les deux classes de votre école indienne de Pointe-Blanche.

Après avoir visité le cours régulier de l'année, je tenais à me rendre compte du travail que font les élèves du cours d'été.

59 élèves ont suivi le premier, c'est-à-dire, celui de sept mois; 52 suivent le second qui dure trois mois.

J'ai constaté que les progrès ne sont pas aussi bons qu'ils ne l'étaient dans le passé. L'expérience faite nous prouve déjà que ce mode n'est guère satisfaisant et donne un résultat inférieur à ce qu'on obtenait auparavant. Le niveau de l'enseignement a certainement baissé et cela se comprend, puisque les élèves n'ont fréquenté l'école que sept mois au lieu de dix, et pour cause d'épidémie, n'en ont eu que six cette année.

Le second groupe n'aura que trois mois de classe et cela dans le temps le plus chaud de l'année.

Vraiment, il vaut mieux revenir à l'ancienne organisation, c'est-à-dire à celle qui est en usage dans toutes les écoles de la province.

En conséquence, je prie votre Département de bien vouloir rétablir l'année scolaire telle qu'elle était: du premier septembre au premier juillet avec les vacances pendant les mois de juillet et août.

Comme l'inscription est de 111 élèves - ce qui est beaucoup trop pour deux classes - je demande, en outre, à votre Département d'ouvrir une troisième classe afin de pouvoir recevoir en même temps tous les enfants de la Réserve. Ainsi, tous bénéficieront des dix mois de classe et les progrès seront plus appréciables.

À cet effet, un local pourra facilement être loué à l'extérieur pour y installer les commerçants sans déranger les deux classes actuelles de l'école.

De cette manière tous feront leur année complète.
le classement sera plus facile et les progrès plus marquants.

En septembre prochain, nous aurons dans toute la province, la fréquentation scolaire obligatoire. Il ne faudrait pas que cette école, administrée par le Gouvernement Fédéral, fasse exception à la règle. Elle doit être organisée de manière à recevoir tous les enfants qui s'y présenteront.

Votre maison d'école a besoin de réparations. Le système de chauffage fait défaut; le plafond, les murs sont tout noircis par la fumée. La peinture ne y paraît plus; elle doit être repeinte, et à l'intérieur et à l'extérieur.

La fournaise ne donne plus aucune satisfaction; elle devrait être remplacée par une autre à l'air conditionné avec thermostat en haut dans le passage.

Je ne doute pas que le Département des affaires Indiennes verra à ce que ces améliorations se fassent au cours des vacances de manière à ce que son école soit, pour le moins, aussi bien tenue que celles des autres municipalités scolaires, même les plus pauvres.

Votre humble serviteur,

[Signature]

St-Félicien, ce 12 juillet, 1948
The Department of Indian Affairs.

I have visited today both classes of your Indian School at Pointe Bleue.

After visiting the regular course, I wanted to ascertain the work done by the pupils during the summer course.

59 pupils followed the former, that is the 7-month course and 52 are following the second which lasts three months.

I found out that progress was not as satisfactory as in the past. Experience has shown that this system is not very satisfactory and that it gives results inferior to those which were formerly obtained. The educational level has certainly been lowered; and this is easily understood inasmuch as the pupils attended school only 7 months instead of 10 and this year, due to an epidemic, they only had six months schooling.

The second group will only have three months schooling and this in the warmest period of the year.

I believe that it would be preferable to revert to the former system, which is in use in all other schools in the Province.

Accordingly, I would ask the Department to re-establish the former school year: from Sept. 1 to July 1, with holidays during July and August.

Further, as 111 pupils have been registered -- which is too large a number for two classes -- I would ask your Department to open a third class in order to accommodate all the children of the reserve at the same time. Thus, all will benefit from 10 months schooling and progress will be measurably increased.

For this purpose, premises could be easily leased outside the school to accommodate beginners without disturbing the two present classes in the school.

In this manner, all will attend school the whole year, it will be easier to classify them and progress will be more noticeable.

Next September, compulsory school attendance will be inaugurated in the province. This school, which is administered by the Dominion Government, should not be an exception to the rule, and it should be set up in such a manner as to receive all the children which will apply.

The schoolhouse needs repairs. The heating system is defective; the ceilings and the walls have been blackened by smoke. All traces of paint have disappeared and it should be repainted inside and outside.

The furnace is very defective; it should be replaced by an air-conditioning furnace with a thermostat upstairs in the hall.

I have no doubt that the Department of Indian Affairs will see to it that these improvements are carried out during the holidays in order that the school be at least as well kept as those of other municipalities, even the poorest.

Your humble servant,

(Sgd) C.E. Boily,
School Inspector.

With reference to your letter No 21-1-1 dated 21 July, may I inform you that I did not have any interview with Inspector Boily at the time of his visit to the school last July; he simply sent me a copy of the report which he forwarded to you.

I had an interview with Sister Henri-Suzo, who has been a teacher at the Pointe Bleue school for twelve years. For the 1943-44 school year the Sister expects to have 73 children; in the first class there are 35 desks and she expects 30 children; in the second class there are 52 desks whereas 43 pupils are expected. In addition to these 73 pupils there are about 10 white children of school age, from families of C.M.R. section-men and from the family of Willie Larouche who are tolerated on the reserve. Therefore, there would be no need for a third class if we only had to provide for the Indians; it is the last mentioned 10 who would cause overcrowding. Since June 1st, 52 pupils attended the classes; as several of them are hunters' children, if it were not for these summer courses, they could not be educated as they always return from the woods around the summer holidays.

As you may note by Mr. Boily's reports (which I would ask you to return to me) the classes held in 1941 and 1942 were a success. The falling off in attendance this year was obviously caused by epidemics of whooping cough and scarlet fever, but after the quarantine was lifted at the end of November, a few parents kept their children at home until January as they did not think it worth while to send them to school in December. Therefore, for some reason there was a falling off in the educational level.

For this year at least, I am still in favour of holding classes from October 1st to April 30th and from June 1st to August 31st.

RE: Visit to Pointe Bleue Agency

I beg to submit a report of an inspection made at the above agency on July 15, 16 & 17th last.

SCHOOL

My visit happened to be during the summer school term; the sister in charge gave me the list of the forty-seven inscriptions for said term consisting of fifty-four school days. According to records, attendance was as follows:

- 8 pupils attended from 50 to 54 days
- 9 " " " 40 to 50 "
- 10 " " " 30 to 40 "
- 12 " " " 20 to 30 "
- 6 " " " 10 to 20 "
- 2 " " " less than 10 days

The total of 47 inscriptions is made up of:
- Children living on the reserve all the year... 26
- Children living on the reserve during the summer months only (9 speaking "Indian only")... 31 - 47

During the term the 26 children who were able to make up a class by themselves did not easily follow a mixed class.

School Inspector C.E. Boily, rushed when he came to make his examination at the Agency office, and simply mailed his report to the Agent. I have read said report and agree with him on some points.

He does not apparently approve of our system at our school, he said that the uneven number of success was due to an epidemic, there was no attendance; if he only had talked to our school, he would have written a more accurate report, as the majority of the children were ill in October and a part of November. In December many were still ill, and in January many were still ill. One month of January due to an epidemic, one expects to compare results of a school when it really was no more than three months.

When the system was established two years ago into two sections, it was for the children of families (hunters) who...
summer months only and never had a chance to learn to read; the change now existing gave those children a better showing than they ever had before.

Mr. Boily suggests the return to the old school year as carried on in other parts of Quebec, as the new Quebec legislation on compulsory attendance to school will be in effect from September 1943. He does not seem aware that the Indian Act had that matter decided upon a long time before Quebec ever thought about it; I must admit however, that it is hard to enforce the Act where we have no constable.

I do not agree with the Inspector's suggestion to open a third class, claiming that there are ill inscriptions; he forgets that many children can only speak Indians and are unable to follow the regular course for the whole year; he also forgets that many children are following their families to their hunting grounds and therefore unable to attend a ten months school year; this will leave sufficient room in the two classes for the children remaining on the reserve, who are able to follow our longer school term. I fail to see the necessity for another class being opened.

The sisters again complained that the water still tastes of gasoline. I also noticed this taste. They claim to be very careful when filling the engine with gasoline, but it seems to run into the well. I would recommend that we secure an estimate of the cost of moving the small engine in the cellar away from the well. This should not cost very much and I have asked our Agent to secure this information and submit same to the Department for consideration. Our water supply is good and plentiful and the taint of gasoline does not affect it for washing purpose but it is hardly fit for drinking and the Indians cannot be blamed for objecting to drinking it.

The painting and varnishing of the two classrooms will be executed while the children are not attending school.

Annexed hereto is a list of rations as I found them on my visit. In my opinion, every case is justified either by old age or sickness. I am satisfied that no able bodied Indians are on the relief list. Total rations of $366.92 compare favorably with the total of $386.76 of same month in 1942.

There is employment available for Indians who are not in the trapping group; the blueberry season is also bringing quite a number to the fifty or more families who have gone to pick berries some sixty miles away, partly to La Dorée, partly to Lac à la Pêche by truck with their camping outfit; the berries are plentiful this year and four hundred cases have been sold in the market. The cost of transportation by truck is $20. per trip each way, several two or three families sharing the same transport and dividing the cost. The price paid averages $2.50 per quart of nine quarts, the Indians paying twenty five cents for the trip and the trucks are collecting the berries three times per week paying cash on delivery on the road. The picking of blueberries is easy and simple, children can all help and a family of six to five pickers will easily earn from ten to fifteen dollar...
per day and during the season of six to seven weeks, an average family should make easily from five to six hundred dollars. It was reported that last year a family of six (whites) good pickers sold eleven hundred dollars worth of blueberries. That is probably the reason more Indians have gone away to pick blueberries this year.

FARMING

There is not much change in farming and no great improvement can ever be expected until those farmers stick to their farms altogether; too many leave their farms to guide during the fishing and hunting seasons, and I feel that it is very hard to keep them on the farms; then, some do return with cash but too many with little or none; it is not surprising to hear them often say that the farm is not paying, only due most of the time to the many absences. The day we are able to convince them that their farm properly looked after would give them revenue superior to any income from guiding, we will have accomplished something.

Lake ONISTAGAN

A few Indian families did not return to the reserve this summer, and I understand they were organizing to settle at Lake Onistagan, on the west border of our Peribonka Beaver Preserve, where they have their hunting grounds.

These families appear to be amongst some of the best hunters in the Band, and are wanting to settle and lead a more Indian life, away from the whites.

Our agent has sent to these families a supply of old clothing which they requested and we will probably hear more about them when our Mr. Conn visits the Peribonka district.

Extract from Jude Thibault
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Ottawa, September 4, 1943.

Re: Visit to Pointe Bleue Agency

My visit happened to be during the summer school term, the sister in charge gave me the list of the forty seven inscriptions for said term consisting of fifty four school days. According to records, attendance was as follows:

| Pupils | Attended |
|--------|----------|
| 8      | from 50 to 54 days |
| 9      | " 40 to 50 "       |
| 10     | " 30 to 40 "       |
| 12     | " 20 to 30 "       |
| 6      | " 10 to 20 "       |
| 2      | less than 10 days  |

The total of 47 inscriptions is made of:
Children living on the reserve all the year ... 26
with 11 of them speaking "Indian only"

Children living on the reserve during the summer months only (9 speaking "Indian only") ... 21 - 47

During the term the 20 children speaking "Indian only" were able to make up a class by themselves, while they could not easily follow a mixed class.

School Inspector C. L. Boily, must have been in a great hurry when he came to make his examination, as he did not call at the Agency office, and simply mailed a copy of his report to the Agent. I have read said report and beg to differ of opinion with him on some points.

He does not apparently approve of the two course given at our school, he said that the seven months course was not a success, due to an epidemic, there was only a six months attendance; if he only had talked to our agent and got first hand information, he would have written a different and more accurate report, as the majority of the children had scarlet fever in October and a part of November, then, some being convalescent even in December, many were away from school in the month of January due to an epidemic of grippe; how can any one expect to compare results of a supposed seven month term when it really was no more than three months attendance.

When the system was established to divide our school year into two sections, it was with a view to benefit the children of families (hunters) who were on the reserve during the summer months only and never had a chance to learn to read; the change now existing gave those children a better showing than they ever had before.

Mr. Boily suggests the return to the old school year as carried on in other parts of Quebec, as the new Quebec legislation for compulsory attendance to school will be in effect from September 1943. He does not seem aware that the Indian Act had that matter decided upon a long time before Quebec ever thought about it; I must admit however, that it is hard to enforce the Act where we have no constable.
I do not agree with the Inspector's suggestion to open a third class, claiming that there are ill inscriptions; he forgets that many children can only speak Indian and are unable to follow the regular course for the whole year; he also forgets that many children are following their families to their hunting grounds and therefore unable to attend a ten months school year; this will leave sufficient room in the two classes for the children remaining on the reserve, who are able to follow our longer school term. I fail to see the necessity for another class being opened.

The sisters again complained that the water still tastes of gasoline. I also noticed this taste. They claim to be very careful when filling the engine with gasoline, but it seems to run into the well. I would recommend that we secure an estimate of the cost of lining the well with lead or similar, away from the well. This should not cost very much and I have asked our Agent to secure this information and submit same to the Department for consideration. Our water supply is good and plentiful and the taint of gasoline does not affect it for washing purpose but it is hardly fit for drinking and the Indians cannot be blamed for objecting to drinking it.

The painting and varnishing of the two classrooms will be executed while the children are not attending school.
Ottawa,
September 14, 1943.

Yours truly,

I wish to inform you that I had an interview with Sister Henri-Suzo, teacher, Principal of the Pointe Bleue School, who told me that her pupils had been successful in the course of the year, and we came to the conclusion that, in order to obtain full results, it would be necessary to close the school on June 30 and reopen it on September 1, as was done formerly.

In order that the hunters' children benefit from the tuition given, it would be necessary that a teacher (nun) be engaged for July only. The classes have been closed these last two years because the Indians bring their children with them to pick up blueberries.

In compliance with your request, here is a brief report covering the latter:

In the first place, all those who are charged with education agree with me. The ideal method would be ten consecutive months of school, with an additional month for Indians, which would be sufficient for the latter because they are not on the Reserve any longer. Those arriving previous to July can attend the half-breed class where they will be admitted.

This year more than ever, I have studied the matter and am giving briefly what I have noted.

Firstly, during the first days of June I had no pupils, and only three or four some days later; seven pupils by the end of the month.

In July, there were twenty admissions -- they have generally taken fairly good advantage of it.

In August, no pupils.

I therefore sincerely feel that it would be better to have ten consecutive months of school. I can assure you that we cannot give to these pupils in seven months the tuition which we would normally be required to give in ten months; it is quite impossible.

Moreover, during the five months' holiday our pupils forget, and when they return to school some have to repeat. They become discouraged and this delays them considerably for the Solemn Communion which requires them to be in the sixth year.

There are many other disadvantages which space here does not permit me to bring to your attention.

Kindly accept my grateful thanks for all you have done for us until this day, and forgive me for the worries which I may have caused you. I hope you will continue to promote this case to a good end in order that we may attain the proposed aim, because it is totally for the good of all.

(Sgd) Soeur Henri-Suzo, B.C.

DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC EDUCATION
Quebec.

No. 334-Col

Quebec, September 5th., 1947.

SER 9 1947

The Indian Affairs Branch,

Dear Sir,

For the past several years, the Department has been maintaining a small school for the benefit of about 15 white children at Pointe Bleue, in the County of Roberval.

In view of the difficulties encountered in the organization and maintenance of this class and as there is already, in the locality, a well organized Convent under the control of your Department, it is thought these children should attend such Convent and that it is not advisable for us to continue maintaining this small independent school.

We are aware of the fact that according to your regulations, white children are not allowed to attend the Indian school. If our information is correct however, the only white children in the locality are those of Mr. Tremblay who, being section-hand, can hardly reside elsewhere. In regard to the others they are half-breeds, the father being white and the mother Indian. In addition, the Pointe Bleue authorities, the Reverend the Parish Priest, Mr. De La Boissière and the Chief of the tribe are willing to accept these children at the Convent.

In the interest of the education of these children, would it not be possible for your Department to give to the person concerned the authority to accept these children in the classes of the Convent.

It is with confidence that we are submitting this request and we are convinced that it will receive your best attention.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) J.P. Labarre,
Superintendent of Public Education.

Québec, le 5 septembre 1947.

Au Département des Affaires Indiennes,
Ottawa.

Cher Monsieur,

Depuis quelques années, le Département maintient une petite école au bénéfice d'une quinzaine d'enfants blancs, à Pointe Bleue dans le comté de Roberval.

Vu les difficultés que nous rencontrons dans l'organisation et le maintien de cette classe et vu qu'il existe déjà dans la localité, un couvent bien organisé sous le contrôle de votre Département, nous estimons que ces enfants devraient fréquenter ce couvent et qu'il n'y a pas lieu pour nous de continuer de maintenir en activité la petite école indépendante.

Nous savons que, d'après vos règlements, les enfants des blancs ne peuvent fréquenter l'école des Indiens. Toutefois, si nos renseignements sont exacts il n'y a en fait de blancs dans cette localité que les enfants de monsieur Tremblay, qui est cantonnier et qui peut difficilement demeurer ailleurs. Quant aux autres, ce sont des métis. Le père est blanc, mais la mère est sauvagesse. De plus, les autorités de la Pointe Bleue, le Révérend Père Curé, monsieur De La Boissière, le chef de la tribu, sont prêts à accepter ces enfants au couvent.

Dans l'intérêt de l'instruction de ces enfants, votre Département ne pourrait-il pas donner à qui de droit l'autorisation d'accepter ces enfants dans les classes du couvent.

C'est avec confiance que nous vous adressons cette demande et nous sommes convaincus qu'elle recevra votre meilleure attention.

Veuillez me croire, cher monsieur,

Votre tout dévoué,

Le Surintendant de l'Instruction publique.

J.-P. Labarre

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF INDIAN EDUCATION

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School

There is an enrolment of 20 pupils in grades V, VI, VII, and IX under the direction of the senior teacher. There are 33 pupils in grades III and IV, and 49 in grades I and II. Grades III and IV are combined and are taught in the parish hall which is quite unsatisfactory as a classroom. It is being used as an emergency.

It is recommended to build a classroom, plan 865. A male teacher would take charge of the senior boys. According to the present enrolment there would be approximately 20 pupils. Grades VIII and IX should attend provincial High Schools. There will be 6 in this category next year. The principal has been instructed to notify the Department as soon as the final standing of these pupils is known.

There seems to be some misunderstanding between Roberval and the reserve. There is not here the cooperation that is noticed at Lorette, Pierreville, and other localities which now show a great deal of goodwill towards the Indian. This misunderstanding seems to be caused principally by ignorance of Government policy on the part of the authorities in Roberval. In order that activities on the reserve be successful I believe that this misunderstanding should be cleared as soon as possible.

Respectfully submitted,

A. J. Dace
Supervisor, Vocational Education.

L'année des rapports a été retardée parce qu'elles refusaient de faire signer par les institutrices attitrées de l'école.

Ottawa, October 6, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, informing the Department of the change in teachers for the current school year at the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School.

In this connection I have to say that the appointment of Sister Marie du Carmel as principal, to replace Sister St. Louis, and of Sister Henri-Suze, as assistant teacher, is approved.

Sister Marie du Carmel will be paid salary at the rate of $600 and Sister Henri-Suze, $500 per teaching year.

You should have advised the Department before the school re-opened of the change in teachers, as cheques in payment to the former teachers for the month of September have been sent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. de la Boissiere, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue,
Que.

Representative of the Treasury,

Re School No. 325

May 21, 1937

L.W. McCutcheon,
Chief Treasury Officer.

Dear sir,

Received yesterday the cheque salary intended to Sister Marie du Carmel. Please accept my most grateful thanks for all the measures she has taken for the settlement of this question. Having destroyed the original, I hope not to give other trouble for this subject in future.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School
No. 325

In my memorandum of July 13, 1943, I advised you of the period that this school would be in operation during the academic year 1943-44.

Please note that this school will be in operation for the current academic year for the months of June, July and August, 1943, November and December, 1943, January, February, March and April, 1944. From the above you will note that no payment should be made to the teachers for the months of September and October, 1943, or for the month of May, 1944. Sister Henri-Suzo and Sister Marie Raphael will continue in charge of the school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
June 28, 1943.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School
No. 325

In my memorandum of June 16, I advised you of the period during which this school will be in operation for the academic year 1943-44. For the last three years we have been operating this school for only a nine-month period, but this year it will be operated for a ten-month period. I, therefore, submit the following corrected statement regarding the months during which this school will be open:

1943 - June, July, August, October, November and December;

1944 - January, February, March and April.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
November 5, 1943.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School, No. 325.

Please note that Sister Marie Raphael has given up duties at this school and was replaced by Sister Ste. Bernadette, effective October 1, 1943, at a salary of $50.00 a month. The necessary forms will be forwarded to you as soon as possible. Please note that the teachers at this school from October 1, 1943, are Sister Henri Suzo and Sister Ste. Bernadette.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
March 21, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School, No. 325.

I desire to refer you to memorandum of June 28, 1943, giving the dates during which this school would be open in 1943 and part of 1944. From that memorandum you will note that the salaries of the teachers should be paid for the months of January, February, March and April, 1944.

The school will be closed for the month of May, 1944, and for the month of September, 1944. Salary should, therefore, be paid the teachers for the months of June, July and August, 1944.

The school will re-open on October 1, 1944, and will be in continuous operation to April 30, 1945.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa,
March 20, 1944.

Mr. A. de la Boissiere, Indian Agent, Pointe Bleue, Que.

I have your letter of the 9th instant, regarding the months during which the Principal of the Pointe Bleue School has asked that the school be operated.

In official letter of August 19, 1943, it was decided to operate the Pointe Bleue School from October 1, 1943, to April 30, 1944, and from June 1, 1944, to August 31, 1944.

The Department feels that these dates should be given a fair trial. A very careful record should be kept of the attendance during the period October 1 to April 30 and also during the period June 1 to August 31. With regard to the latter period, we wish to know if the children who are absent from the reserve in the winter time attend school regularly during the summer period.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
June 16, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School, No. 325.

The following is a statement regarding the months during which this school will be open:

1944 -- June, July, August, October, November and December.

1945 -- January, February, March and April.

For Deputy Minister.
Ottawa,
May 9, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School, No. 325.

I desire to direct your attention to our memorandum of June 28, 1943. The Pointe Bleue School closed for one month's holidays on April 30 and will re-open on June 1. No salary should be paid to the teachers for the month of May, 1944.

for Deputy Minister.

Memorandum:

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School,
No. 325.

I desire to refer you to my memorandum of May 15, 1945, with reference to the opening and closing dates of this school during the academic year 1945-46.

It has now been decided to keep this school in operation for the months of May and June, 1946, and salary for both those months should be paid to the teachers.

For Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, July 11, 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School No. 325

Please note that this school will be in operation for the month of July, 1946.

Only one teacher, Sister Henri-Suzo, will be in charge for that month, therefore, she is the only one to be paid.

for Deputy Minister.

Memorandum:

for Deputy Minister.

Monsieur le Secrétaire,
Dépt des Affaires des Sauvages,
Ottawa,

Monsieur,

En réponse à votre très-honorée du 20 août 1919, numéro 152684-5, à propos du compte de la maison J. A. Guay, de Montréal, vous trouverez ci-attaché un coupon de mandat-poste représentant le paiement du compte de cette maison.

En effet, en 1917, avec l'autorisation du Département, les Institutrices de Pointe-Bleue envoyaient une commande à la maison Guay pour des prix qui furent distribués aux élèves de l'école, et elles m'en firent adresser le compte. À la fin de l'année scolaire, un Cercle Dramatique composé des anciennes élèves fut formé, et avec le concours d'autres personnes, ce Cercle donna à la Réserve en juillet de la même année une soirée dramatique et un euchre au profit de bonnes œuvres.

Parmi ces œuvres, vu qu'on était en temps de guerre, je suggérai aux jeunes filles de payer les prix de l'école avec les recettes des soirées. Ce qui fut agréé. Les recettes la première année s'élevèrent à $ 47.00. Je transmis à Melle Alice L. Cleary, qui en était la secrétaire, le compte de la maison Guay pour qu'elle payât. Six ou sept mois plus tard, je reçus un état de compte de la même maison qui m'en demandait la remise. Je l'adressai de nouveau à Melle Cleary, qui faisait alors la classe à Roberval et qui me fit savoir qu'elle allait le solder. Au mois de juin dernier, je reçus encore un état de compte, me disant que s'il n'était pas payé sans délai, on allait l'adresser au Département pour paiement. J'avertis Melle Cleary qui me laissa sous l'impression qu'elle avait envoyé le montant du compte et qu'elle m'en ferait tenir le reçu.

Par votre lettre, j'apprends que le compte n'avait pas encore été payé et je me suis adressé à la présidente du Cercle pour savoir s'il y avait encore des fonds disponibles. Il restait encore...
encore $32.00. J'ai téléphoné à Melle Cleary qui était en promenade à Roberval, qui m'a répondu qu'elle me faisait parvenir le coupon du mandat qu'elle avait adressé ce matin même à la maison Guay, et que je viens de recevoir ce soir.

Je dois ajouter que c'est grâce aussi à la libéralité de ce Cercle qu'on a pu distribuer quelques prix aux élèves de l'école à la fin des années scolaires 1918-19, sans recourir au Département.

J'ai l'honneur d'être,

Monsieur,

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Agent des Sauvages.
Sir,

In reply to your esteemed letter of Aug. 20, 1918, No. 15264-5, in connection with the account of the J.A. Guay firm, of Montreal, you will find attached hereto a receipt for a post office order representing the payment of the account of this firm.

As a matter of fact, in 1917, at the authorization of the Department the teachers of Pointe Bleue sent an order to the Guay firm for prizes which were distributed to the pupils of the school and they sent the account to me. At the end of the scholastic year a dramatic society composed of ex-pupils was formed with many other people and this society gave at the reserve in July of the same year a dramatic entertainment and a euchre for the benefit of good works. Among these works, in view of the fact that it was in time of war, I suggested to the young girls to pay for the school prizes with the receipts of the entertainment. This was agreed to. The receipts the first year amounted to $47.00. I forwarded to Miss Alice L. Cleary who was the secretary, the account from the Guay firm to be paid. Six or seven months later I received a statement of the account from the same firm asking for settlement. I forwarded it again to Miss Cleary, who was then teaching at Roberval, and who informed me that she was going to settle it. In the month of June last I received another statement of the account telling me that it was not paid without delay it would be sent to the Department. I notified Miss Cleary, who left me under the impression that she had sent the amount of the account and that she would let me have the receipt. By your letter I learned that the account had not yet been paid and I wrote to the president of the society to know if there were still any funds available. There still remained $32.00. I phoned to Miss Cleary who was at Roberval, who replied to me that she was sending me the receipt of the order that she had sent that same morning to the Guay firm and I received it this evening.
I may add that it is thanks also to the liberality of the association that it was possible to distribute some prizes to the children of the school at the end of the scholastic year 1918-19 without recourse to the Department.

I have, &c.,

A. Tessier,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

We absolutely need a new stove to heat the Indian school. The present one is broken all to pieces and it is a constant danger for fire. The pipe is in the same state; it has only the thickness of a sheet of tissue paper, and also full of holes.

I wish you would kindly authorize me to buy a new stove and the necessary pipe. It must be replaced at once so as to remove any danger of fire.

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, October 12th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the last instant, informing the Department that a new stove is required for the use of the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a stove suitable for the requirements of this school, and also for the stove pipe required. Before making the purchase, however, you should obtain prices from a number of firms and purchase the stove from the one quoting the lowest price. After the stove has been delivered you should forward properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, to which you should attach a memorandum showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted by them. While a stove to meet the requirements should be obtained, it is desired that no undue expenditure be incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

To repair the girls' and boys' lavatories, and replace the pieces of wood which are rotten and broken;

Dear Sir,

Enclosed herewith you will find account for the repairs made to the Indian school house at Pointe Bleue. This work, of urgent need, was authorized by Mr. J. D. Sutherland, during my last visit to the Department in April last.

I could not have this work done sooner as during the course of the summer, tradesmen were asking too high prices; twice as high as the prices obtained this fall. The work was getting scarce everywhere.

I have asked tenders for this work and am enclosing those which I have received. The work has been done by F. X. Eugene Roy, the lowest tenderer, and is satisfactory in every way. It took more than five days to carry out the work, besides the cost of materials.

The pupils of the school have not been disturbed by this work as all the interior work was done during holidays and after school hours.

Sir:-

The Indian Chief of Pointe Bleue has handed me a resolution of the Council asking me to write to the Department to obtain the immediate construction of a school on the reserve of Pointe Bleue to replace the old one.

I understand the necessity of the construction of a new school house here, but we could proceed a little more cautiously.

The school is really too small for the number of children. It is a very old building. Any repairs made to that building would be lost money, so that it would be better to build a new house, but I believe it could be used for at least another year.

Nous soussignés, Monte Robertson, Joseph Robertson, David Malachi, Daniel Gill, Conseillers au Conseil des Sauages de la Pointe Bleue du Lac St-Jean, dans la Province de Québec, assemblés récemment et délibérant d'après l'article 124, lettre f., of the Indian Act, 1866 et amendé en 1875, etc., après avoir réfléchi et dans toute la plénitude de nos droits adoptons les résolutions suivantes :

1° Considérant que notre école a été condamnée comme insalubre par le Docteur Constantine de Roberval, le 20 avril 1825.

2° Considérant que dans une classe de 25 élèves, il y a seulement 12 pupitres de 2 places chacun, il y a 6 élèves d'inscrits avec une moyenne d'assistances de 5/10, sans compter les enfants sauvages qui doivent nous arriver bientôt des bois.

3° Considérant que la ventilation est déficiente et que l'école est très froide l'hiver, les enfants ont été obligés de recouvrir les fondations avec de la neige pour ne pas trop souffrir du froid.
Considérant que notre Agent, Messieurs, nous a laissés entendre que nous avions l'île de cette année 1825, que même elle laissera entre de à la Réserve Noire Générale des Sous de Bon Conseil ; ainsi qu'à La Grande Mère qui est l'Église de Chicoutimi.

Considérant que nous sommes bien avisés que les Écoles de Louvres ne sont donc pas des écoles étrangères dans cette ville et nous avons sans contradiction.

Considérant que l'Inspection de l'école Messieurs E. Boily a fait des rapports défavorables sur cette ville école et elle dépend de nous, et qu'il s'insiste fortement sur la nécessité d'une école conservable.

Considérant tous les sacrifices que l'on fait tous les chefs du gouvernement fédéral et provincial, les chefs du bureau d'hygiène, les chefs de villes ou conseillers des Municipalités rurales et scolaires en un mot tous les chefs spirituels et temporels du Canada tout entier pour empêcher et diminuer la mortalité infantile, commençant les causes de la tuberculose.

Considérant que si vous connaissez la vérité, fiez-vous aux barbares, vous n'auriez pas le cœur assez dur pour laisser nos enfants entrassés comme des galeries dans cette maison trop étroite, insalubre, malentendue et les guides à diverses fins.

We undersigned, Meride Robertson, Joseph Robertson, David Malech, Xavier Gill, Councillors of the Indian Council of Pointe Bluse, of Lac St-Jean, in the Province of Quebec, regularly assembled made a resolution according to Section 84, Letter F, of the Indian Act, 1906, and amended in 1910, etc., after discussion and in accordance with the extent of our rights we have adopted the following motions:

1ST: Considering that our school has been condemned as insanitary by Dr. Constantin, of Roberval, on the 20th of April, 1925,

2ND: Considering that there is only one class room of 25 X 15' in which there are twelve (12) desks of two (2) seats each; there are sixty-one (61) pupils registered with an average attendance of fifty-seven (57) pupils, without counting the Indian children who will soon arrive from the bush.

3RD: Considering that the ventilation is defective and that the school is very cold in Winter, and that children were obliged to bank snow around it so as not to suffer too much from the cold.

4TH: Considering that our Agent, Mr. Tessier, left us to understand that we would have a new school this year, 1925, and has also told the same thing to the Reverend Sister who is Mother General of the Sisters of the Good counsel, as well as to His Grace Archbishop of Chicoutimi.

5TH: Considering that we have been notified that the said Reverend Sisters would not continue to teach in this old school and that we will remain without teachers.

6TH: Considering that the Inspector of the school Mr. E. Bolly, has made unfavourable reports against our old school for several years past and that he insists on the building of a new appropriate school.

7TH: Considering all the sacrifices which are borne by the Chiefs of the Federal and Provincial Governments, the Chiefs of the Board of Hygiene, the Councillors of the Towns or Councillors of the Rural Municipalities and School Boards, in one word all the spiritual and temporal Chiefs in Canada to wipe out and diminish the mortality among children as well as the harm caused by Tuberculosis.
