I have only received your letter of May 7th, informing me of the receipt of the Departmental Circular No. 1000 as a new school house at Pointe-à-la-Croix during the summer.

The site of the present school is altogether unsuitable for the purpose now desired, because the land is not sufficiently large, the ground is steep and too near the railway line, so near that when the passengers leave the train they have to make an angle so that they would not touch the school house.

The building itself is surrounded by small houses or shacks which are a constant danger of fire.

After having visited several places I came to the conclusion, with the Chief and all the committee of the Tribe, who are of the same opinion, that the best place for the erection of the new school house at Pointe-à-la-Croix would be just off the road to the Church and in straight line with the Church and the majority of the Ojibwa families. It is a beautiful spot situated on a hill about forty feet high and dominating the whole Indian Village. The ground is dry, sheltered by trees, there is about two feet thick soil and loam with a rock bottom, and this spot is right in the middle of the Reserve. It has been previously chosen for the building of the church, but it was finally built on the grave of the Ojibwa Father, on lot 123. The lot has 13 acres, about 215 feet in width, with a depth of two acres, being a parcel of land 360 x 215. This would be quite sufficient for a play ground and a well laid garden. The improvements on this ground were made by the Ojibwa Father before his death, but the water and a mound occupied the time I was here and therefore I cannot give any information regarding the improvements. They would be rather cheap, being less than $50 per acre for good arable land. He told me that he had seen them much more than the price asked for to make the improvements, but seeing that it was for the erection of the school, he will not ask for more. If we had to place the school anywhere else we would have to pay for the improvements of the land, a much higher price. Then would be no road to build to go to that school, as the church road would be insufficient.

Therefore I believe I must recommend this spot as the most suitable and most central if we can get. Every one here agrees to say that it is an ideal spot for the erection of a school house. I have sketched a small plan which you will find attached herewith and which will give you a better idea of the proposed site.

I would recommend that the school house be built by day labour under the supervision of a good foreman.
and here are the reasons why, to begin with a contractor would build it to make money, that is to draw as much profit out of his contract as possible, he would look into the benefits he can make to the difference in the quality of the work and materials used. Even if he was the most conscientious contractor, he will be looking in spite of attention to the expenditure and if he sees that he is not making enough money he will hold the whole thing.

Supposing the cost of the building would be just as high then that backed by a contractor, the percentage going to him as a profit, would be put on the building to obtain better work and a superior quality of materials. In our work the work would be better done in every way, the presence being no profits to appear over the materials nor the wages of the labourers. It would be easy to hire or form an a good mechanic who would direct the work while working himself. All the materials could be purchased by tender and specify as specified any of the quality mentioned in the specifications and plans.

This would also give a chance to our Indians to see something in the kind of work they could do.

If I was only thinking of the appearance this would give me I would surely recommend that the work be given by contract.

Pointe-Blanc, Dec 10th 1934

Sir,

I am forced by circumstances to submit the following report concerning the school house on the reserve at Pointe-Blanc.

That building is more dilapidated than ever; it is extremely cold, air and wind penetrate from all sides, the stone foundations are cracked, and full of holes which make the floor very cold to the feet. It has moved so much through frost that the glasses were broken.

The teacher called me at the school a few days ago so that I might find by myself how cold that house is. In fact, by noon, when the stove was heating to its full capacity, all the children and the teacher were suffering from cold. The teacher has warned me they certainly would not continue to teach in that class room during the winter under these conditions. We will have to choose one of the following alternatives: either give a holiday during the months of February, the colder part of the season, and keep the school open during July and August except Summer; or, if you wish to continue the school this winter, to change the kind of heating and have urgent repairs made. The school is heated at present with wood; the stove is lighted at 6 in the morning. The ink in the inkstands is frozen every morning. It would be necessary to make the school habitable, that is to say heated day and night, the wood stove should be replaced by a furnace heater and heater with coal. For this it would be necessary to purchase a furnace for furnace heater and five tons of coal and make certain repairs which would amount to about $150. or $175.

This is the only way to attain a satisfactory result as I said before, or give two-months holiday during January and February.
This school has always been very difficult to heat. Until the 8th November last and for 15 years, I always attended personally to the lighting of the stove in the school and further work I was getting from the Dept. the sum of $25.00. When I was unable to do it I had someone to do it for me for $25 or $35. Last year I did the same thing while when I was unable to perform the work myself, I had somebody to replace me at my own expense. As for the preceding year, I had drawn my accounts for $25.00 in 1925 to the Dept. On the 7th June, under no. 14-21, I received a letter from the Dept., asking me if I had performed the work myself. I immediately replied what is written here above, and I regret to say that I have not yet been paid.

In spite of all, this fall I continued to light the stove of the school until the 7th November. I could not find anybody who would take the job for less than $20 to $25 for the Winter, which was out of proportion. On the 7th November, Mrs. Wilson, Mary Robertson offered me to light the stove of the school. She has two big boys who can help her. She was asking at first $15.00 per month and finally accepted $6.00 per month, on condition that she should be paid every month or at least every second month. I tried her for one month and found to be quite satisfactory, but it was not of her fault if the school is hard to heat on account of being so dilapidated. Here is the work she has to do; light the stove about 6 o'clock in the morning for the breakfast time and then heat the stove from 7 to 10 o'clock. I imagine herself the stove rooms on Sundays and holidays. I imagine her work is more than fair. I am paying her $6.00 per month for lighting the stove from the 8th November to the 8th December. Also the Account of Proper Supplies for 8½ cords of wood supplied to the school. I will not purchase any other wood before you advise me if you wish to continue the contract next winter and be closer for January and February.

Yours etc., (Signed) Leonard Tucker

Sir,

I have your letter of the 10th instant, reporting on the condition of the school building at Pointe Bleue and stating that it will be impossible for the teachers to carry on the work without extensive repairs being undertaken.

In reply I beg to say that the Department agrees with you that it would be advisable to close this school during the months of January and February next rather than incur any large expense in fitting up the building, in view of the fact that, if the necessary funds are provided, it is the intention to erect a new school building.

You may, therefore, inform the Reverend Sisters that the school is to remain closed during the two above-mentioned months. They should, however, arrange to re-open the school on or about the first of March next and keep it open during July and August following.

Il m'a fallu me chicaner à plusieurs reprises avec l'entrepreneur pour le faire agir de bonne foi, chicanes qui ont fini d'égayer plusieurs fois en combat de boxe. De loin, comme à Ottawa, supposons, pareille surveillance paraît simple et facile, mais de près, ce n'est pas tant à fait la même chose.

J'ai l'honneur d'être, humain,

Sir— In reply to your letter of the 10th October, No. 21-15, I respectfully submit that I would have no objection to recommend that the old school building, after the new one be inaugurated, be left at the disposal of the Indians of Pointe-Blanc to use it as a Council Hall, but I foresee that a great deal of expense will be necessary to put it in good shape.

The stone foundation practically needs to be rebuilt; the lower part of the frame of the building is rotten as well as the walls. The porch is altogether gone. The roof wants new shingles and the chimney would also need to be repaired.

This old wooden building is more than 50 years old and would necessitate a considerable expenditure to be put in good shape.

When they saw a new schoolhouse was being erected, several Indians asked me if the old building could be put up. I replied them that seeing that many of them wanted to buy the material that could be used again, it would be most likely sold by auction so as to give everybody the same chance to buy.

The Indian Council meets two or three times a year, either at my office or at the schoolhouse, and I do not see why they could not continue to do so.

However, if the Indians do wish to keep the old house there it as a Council House, I would suggest that they take charge of all repairs and work of restoration at their expense, which could easily be done by subscription, I am positive.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, relative to the request of the Indians that the old school building at Pointe Bleue be handed over to be used as a council hall.

In reply I beg to say that in view of the present condition of this old building and the cost involved in repairing same, it is considered that it would be advisable for you to arrange for the sale of same. The money received for the sale of the building should be forwarded by you to the Department for credit of the Receiver General. We note that the Indians can very well use either your or ice or the new school building for the holding of their council meetings on the two or three times each year which they meet. The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa

Sir,

In reference to your letter of the 23rd Nov. last, No. 21-1-5 concerning the installation of a hot air furnace in the new Indian school at Poveshell. I would say that after I met the agent who "knew best" and submitted a tender for $500.00, I had better take note of Mr. Gurney's local agent of the Supreme furnaces of Port Hope, Ontario. He was accompanied by Mr. Cote, general salesman of the same company. The "Supreme" furnace is certainly superior in every way to the "New Idea" for our district. It is best adapted to our climate. A large number of these furnaces have been installed at St. John in the last few years where they appear perfectly satisfactory. A large number of schools in this district as well as public buildings and private residences have "Supreme" furnaces.

I telephoned to four or five different persons to know if their furnaces were giving satisfaction; they all told me they were perfectly satisfied. I went to see one myself at St. Anne and was amazed by its simplicity and the ease with which it can be handled. This furnace is economizing fuel. In accordance with your letter of the 15th of October last, No. 21-1-5, I am forwarding the account of Mr. Pierre Davel for the boring of the artesian well for the new Indian School at Pointe-Blanc. The first time water was struck it was at a depth of 183 feet. The well was drilled 5 feet more, 188 feet to be sure of sufficient supply. At the trial which was made for some consecutive hours in presence of the Commissioners of the Tribe, who were there also when the depth was measured, the well gave 100 gallons per hour. The water was pumped and then again an hour later. This repeated for 4 hours. There are several wells at Pointe-Blanc and this one is among those giving the largest quantity of water per hour.

It was drilled at a distance of about 4½ feet from the school walls. To have the pump which will be installed, no matter what system it is, clear from frost, it will be necessary to have an above adjoining the cellar where the basement of the cellar can circulate, as it was done at the Agent's residence, and which is giving entire satisfaction. WHEN a new school building is nearing completion, or old rooms are to be refitted, one of the first and most important items of equipment to receive attention is furniture. Too much care in its selection cannot be exercised, because the expenditure so represented not only constitutes a large sum, but the purchase must be made from a viewpoint of true economy. Sir:

They should be set up in rows of the same size desks, with a front and rear seat for each row. It is hoped, when these desks arrive, that they will be satisfactory and will provide seating accommodation for a total of 84 pupils.

SPECIFICATIONS FOR PUMP

LUBRICATION
Perfect lubrication of the "piston type" cross-head is a Patented and exclusive Duro feature. Porous plugs in the cylindrical crosshead permit an even automatic oil flow. This feature is fool-proof and eliminates the possibility of excess lubrication.

OILING
Each of the bearings (including the connecting rod) has its own oil reservoir with wool waste circulating system. This is an exclusive Duro Feature eliminating troublesome grease cups with a loss of lubrication through grease squeezing out. It eliminates manual lubrication as there are no grease cups.

CRANK SHAFT
The Duro one-piece, high-carbon, drop-forged ground steel crankshaft is of the center-throw type hung on two phosphor bronze bearings, insuring higher efficiency.

DIFFERENTIAL
The Duro differential eliminates the necessity of the stuffing box. This principle results in an even motor load and an even flow of water, as it pumps on both up and down strokes. That's why Duro Deep Well Pumps are so quiet and efficient.

LOWER CYLINDER
Is of the open type allowing the lower Valve and Plunger to withdraw without destroying the Drop Pipe or Cylinder.

COMPACTNESS
Duro Deep Well Pumps require very little room. They are easily gotten at from all sides. The motor is up high and away from all possible dampness. The square base permits setting pump head in any direction.

CHAIN DRIVE
The Chain Drive is standard on Duro Deep Well Pumps. There are no worm gears to reduce efficiency.

QUIET
Duro construction eliminates noise. The plunger leathers are especially treated for long life and to minimize friction, thus preventing overload.

SAFE
The pump mechanism is totally enclosed in one rigid casting, fully protected and guarded.

The hearty welcome received last year about the school at Pointe-Blanc brings me back to you for the same cause.

I believe it is my duty to inform the Department of Indian Affairs that I am convinced they ignore concerning this school, as the real state of affairs is pitiful. I know the legitimate ambition of the Department concerning the schools under its control and I dare rely on its devotion to have this warning taken into consideration.

The old school, which had to be closed during January and February 1927, is no more habitable than it was then. Besides the cold temperature in the building, the snow blows in, and at present it is still only by 10 a.m. that it starts to melt on the teacher's desk; window panes were missing, in the fall, have not been replaced; etc.

Although I am giving you here a little idea of the situation, it will be easy to understand that the health of the pupils and the teacher is greatly compromised and an immediate improvement is absolutely necessary.

Your kindness is our only recourse and we expect this favour with so much more confidence that we had to wait longer for it. Kindly receive our best regards and thanks.

(Signed) M. St. Cyprien, general superior

May 6, 1928.

MEMORANDUM: Mr. [signature]

While at Pointe Bleue last week I made an inspection, in company with Mr. Plourde, the contractor, of the new school building lately completed on this reserve. The building appears to be well constructed, - the blackboards, however, have been installed above the wainscoting which is much too high for the younger pupils, and I consequently authorized the contractor to build raised platforms wherever required by the Sisters. As the school will be occupied within a few days the contractor was also requested to erect temporary outside closets.

Owing to the constant presence of water in the basement of this building it will be necessary that the drainage and sewerage systems be immediately installed. The work will consist in the laying of 125 feet of 6" vitrified drain pipe, and the construction of a concrete septic tank, with an outlet into the ditch along the railway track, all of which will cost in the neighborhood of $1,000.00. I would recommend if this work is authorized that it be entrusted to Mr. Plourde, the contractor for this building, who is willing to undertake it for the price mentioned. I may say that the excavation for this work will have to be done entirely in solid rock. Of course this matter can stand should the appointment of a permanent agent be made in the course of a short time.

It is also necessary to install in the basement of the school two or three water closets and one wash basin.

MEMORANDUM: School Branch

While at Pointe Bleue last week I made another inspection of the new school building in company with the Acting Indian Agent, and beg to furnish you with the following information concerning the above mentioned building.

The raised platform supplied by the contractor as an extra to enable the younger pupils to use the blackboards in the classrooms, is entirely unsatisfactory and it is understood with the contractor that these shall be taken away from the building and that no payment will be claimed for this additional work.

I would suggest that new steps be built by a competent carpenter during the coming holidays, in accordance with the sketch which the superior has agreed to furnish, if authorized to do so.

The double door at the rear entrance was broken down by the wind. This door should be re-adjusted and provided with a suitable cylinder lock at the expense of the Department. The registers for the intake of the cold air in connection with the hot air heating system, have been adjusted in the floor in a permanent manner. It will be necessary that these be taken out and re-adjusted with screws so that they may be removed for the cleaning of the galvanized iron box underneath them, where dust and waste paper have accumulated.
I may add that I was surprised to find a number of labourers engaged in the levelling of the ground in the front of the school building and upon further inquiry to be advised that the contractor had completed the construction of the sewage disposal system in the manner outlined in his tender for this work, already on file. I subsequently endeavoured to locate Mr. Plourde, the contractor, who is working at Kenogami, and he explained to me that the sewage work was undertaken to prevent the renewal of the flooding of the basement of the building, where a hot-air heating system is installed. He was under the impression that this course would be sanctioned by the Department in view of the urgent need of the work being carried out.

I beg to suggest that the Agent be requested to further investigate this matter and advise the Department whether it would be justified in giving its approval to the action taken by the contractor concerning the above mentioned work. In the affirmative, the Department should be furnished with the Voucher giving an accurate detailed statement of the amount and nature of the work performed, and the rate of payment should not exceed that mentioned in the offer already made by the contractor.

Sr. Superior has agreed to furnish. An Exclusive Emco Process

All the metal entering into the manufacture of Emco products is melted in electric furnaces. In all other methods of melting the fuel used requires the use of oxygen or air for combustion, and even though every precaution is taken, the air or oxygen is bound to come in contact with the heated metal and unite with it, forming oxides of zinc, tin or lead, which, when the metal is poured, tends to make a porous casting.

In the electric furnace the presence of air or oxygen is entirely unnecessary, and the charge is melted under air sealed conditions, so that no oxidization whatever occurs.

Silence Where It Is Mostly Needed

The bathroom is generally conceded to be the last place in the house that should advertise its presence with unnecessary noise and the closet is usually the worst offender in this regard.

This is an effective remedy for this condition in the new Emco "Hush" Float Valve, the outstanding features of which are enumerated over leaf. This valve, in common with all other Emco products, is the result of scientific design, highest quality materials and precision workmanship—a guarantee of lasting service and satisfaction.
Improvements in the new Emco 'Hush' Float-Valve

1. A removable axis pin held in place with a simple locking device. A slight turn of the bent projecting end and the pin is withdrawn, facilitating rapid removal of valve plunger. No inaccessible screws to be removed.

2. The cam contact point is at a minimum distance from the axis of the fulcrum of the float arm. This increases the leverage of the arm and exerts the maximum force, keeping the plunger tightly down on the valve seat.

3. A channel designed to collect and divert to the delivery pipe any water forced past the plunger head, obviating the necessity of any cup leathers which have a tendency to make the plunger stick.

4. Outlet for refill tube so designed as to ensure delivery of the proper amount of water to the bowl during the time the valve is operating.

5. The spiral groove—the feature that contributed, the "hush" sound to the name of the valve and that effectively ensures silent operation. The action of the groove is based on the fact that the water, coming up to allow a circumferential path up the plunger, is subjected to a centrifugal action which has the positive effect of eliminating the singing noise of the old type valve.

6. A cushioned rubber disc, secured by a threaded collar, which facilitates rapid removal and replacement and ensures positive seating.

7. A reversible gate metal seat with the consequent advantage of a double life. Quickly reversed or replaced by unscrewing the union nut. This seat is supplied with two different-sized holes—larger sized hole for medium and low pressures; smaller sized hole for high pressures.

Memorandum:

There has been considerable correspondence with reference to an account of Emile Plourde of St. Prime, Que., who was the contractor for the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School, erected last year. During the late Agent Tessier's illness, Mr. Plourde understood that he was to put in the drain and septic tank. The work was done on a cost plus 10% basis and amounts to $980.46. There was no written authority; but, as both Mr. Indian Agent Boissiere and myself are satisfied that it was necessary and that the work was well done, I have to recommend that the account be paid. I may add that I have inspected the work since its completion, and I find that the heavy labour cost is because the pipe and tank had to be laid in solid rock.

Mr. Plourde has a further account with the Department, which is in order, for repairing, setting up and aligning on strips the school desks and for supplying and installing the fixtures in the cloak rooms. This second account amounts to $285.95.

Departmental Engineer.

Sir:

In beginning of month of February I have noticed that the sewage disposal system of the Indian school was not working. At first I thought that it was just stoped; then I hired few men to look for the trouble and found out that the frost was the cause of it. The sewage drain pipe is all frozen so I have to let it stand like this until the summer. I had to have an outside W.C. erected and for which I am sending you the Return of Labour Sheets. Monsieur,

Il est de mon devoir de vous avertir que le tuyau d'égout de l'école de la Pointe Bleue est gelé. Je l'ai travaillé avec un broche, celle-ci s'est pendue à une vingtaine de pieds en dehors du mur, c'est à cette place qu'il y a un obstacle.

Il faudrait creuser une tranchée à cet endroit, ce qui peut coûter, avec les frais du plombier qui dégèle ce tuyau, environ $50.00 piastres.

Considérant qu'il y a encore 3 mois de classe avant la fin de l'année scolaire, voulez-vous, s.v.p., me donner une autorisation pour faire faire ces travaux.

[signature]

Ottawa, Ont.
Sir,

It is my duty to warn you about the sewer pipe at the school at Pointe-Blanc is frozen. I tried to work it up with a wire, it went to about twenty feet from the wall, that is where there is an obstacle.

It would be necessary to dig a ditch at that place, and that would cost with the plumbers time about $50.00

Considering that there is still 3 months of school before the end of the year, they have asked me to authorize me to have this work done.

Your obedient servant,

A. de la Boissiere
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 17, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, informing the Department that the sewer pipe at the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School is frozen.

In this connection I have to say that you may arrange to have the ditch at the point where the pipe is frozen dug up and the section of pipe which is blocked taken up and the obstruction removed. It is considered that the labour in opening the ditch at the point where the pipe is frozen and the taking up of the section of pipe and replacing same by a new section, if required, should not cost the amount mentioned. It is thought that all this work could be carried out for an amount not exceeding approximately $25. However, you should arrange to have the drain pipe placed in good condition, keeping all expenses for the purpose as low as possible. The placing of the drain in good condition should receive your early attention.

After the work has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the labour and for any new pipe required.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. de la Boissiere, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Pointe-Blanc, Oct. 25th 1931.

Sir,

I have attached herewith four statements of accounts for the amount of $61.00 for materials and labour for the repairs during Feb. 1931 to the sewer of the Indian School at Pointe-Blanc.

This sewer was blocked and frozen, which was causing bad odors and having no outside pipe it was urgent to act immediately. It was also necessary to replace a piece of the pipe which was broken.

I give for the present moment good service.

I take this opportunity to tell you that it will be absolutely necessary during this Summer to have the work to this sewer done on a length of about 120 ft., it is the third time (or fourth) it freezes about the same date. I had done half done earth covered hoping this would prevent frost, this was not a success. Personally I think the pipe is too small being only 8 inches, as it flows fast and they hopes it should be 10 inches in size. Furthermore the pipe is layered only 6 ft. deep at certain places and it would be necessary to plant on the whole length as it is all through rock. It would also be necessary to have the whole duct covered with a fair thickness of saw dust. This work would cost approximately $200.00.

I have the honour to be, Sir, your humble servant,

March 5, 1931.

SCHOOL,

With reference to Indian Agent De la Boissiere's letter of the 25th ultimo hereunder, recommending payment of an account amounting to $61.10 for materials and labour furnished for the repairing of the sewer pipe last month from the Indian School at Pointe Bleue, I beg to say that this sewer pipe was laid in a trench excavated in solid rock with great difficulty. I believe that the reason why it freezes at different points is due to the fact that the ground over its course was lowered when the playground was levelled, after the completion of the sewerage system. In order to avoid further expenditure in connection with this sewer pipe I would recommend that the whole trench be excavated this spring and that the pipe be replaced by a vitrified clay pipe 6" in diameter and that the ground be lowered as much as possible, so that the pipe would be at a depth of 6 feet. The trench should then be filled with earth to a minimum height of 4 feet on top and around the pipe. The cost of the work would be approximately $180.00.

[Signature]

Ottawa, March 7, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing accounts to the total amount of $61.10 for material and labour in carrying out repairs to the sewer at the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School. In reply I have to say that, as our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are entirely exhausted, payment of these accounts cannot be made until after April 1st, next.

It is noted that the sewer is now giving good service, but that you recommend the trench in which the pipe is laid be reopened and deepened during the coming summer and a new pipe of larger dimensions laid. It is doubtful if funds for this purpose can be provided. It is considered that, if precautions are taken by the teachers to see that the pupils do not put extraneous matter in the toilets, there would be little danger of the sewer pipe becoming blocked. Next fall, before the frost sets in, a few loads of manure or straw could be placed along the trench in which the pipe is laid, which would prevent freezing.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the last instant, requesting authority to have the outside walls at the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School painted, the inside walls whitewashed and the floors oiled.

In reply I have to say that our Estimates for the present fiscal year were considerably reduced, and I regret that it will not be possible to authorize the expenditure required in purchasing the materials and for the labour in painting the outside of the building. The Department will, however, approve of you arranging to purchase the materials required and for the labour in having the interior walls whitewashed and the floors oiled. Before the oil is applied, the floor should be well scrubbed and dry. You should see that a satisfactory job is carried out in the whitewashing and oiling of the floor. This work should be completed during the present summer holidays.

After the work is finished, you should forward a certified account, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred for the whitewash, oil and other material used and also for the labour.

Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I have just received all I have asked for the school. I thank you for the rapidity with which you have answered our demands. Service is perfect. There is still a request I wish to make and in presence of your kindness I feel my confidence increasing. Here is my request: I would like to have a small amount of money $10. to $15. to purchase recompense to our pupils before the holidays.

For three years these afflicted and studious children have received no other recompense than that of the Sacred Priest who is much interested in the progress of the pupils; the latter are very obedient, well stimulated by the religious and civil authorities, and certainly deserve a little encouragement to maintain their good application. All laborers deserve a salary and every good pupil a recompense.

You will understand this as I do. I do not want much and I will accept with gratitude whatever you may grant me for our dear little children of the woods who have not seen outside their reserve anything else than wild animals and the tall trees of the forest. Yet they are intelligent and lovable, and if you could see them at school thus cause would be won.

I hope I am not soliciting in vain in their favour and again I thank you for your kindness.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) Sister Marie du Carmel

Monsieur,

Permettez-moi de vous dire que le canal d'égout de l'école à Gérald cet hiver, par conséquent de ce temps-ci il y a un peu d'eau dans la cave due à la fonte de la neige. Dans le moment je fais enlever la terre qui recouvre le tuyau pour favoriser l'égouttement.

Je vous demande donc de bien vouloir m'autoriser pour un montant approximatif de $500.00 pour faire boiser ce tuyau sur une longueur d'environ 100 pas ce qui à mon idée est le meilleur moyen de le protéger contre la gelée.

Pointe Bleue, April 18, 1926.

Sir,

Allow me to inform you that the sewer pipe of the school froze last winter, and consequently there is now some water in the cellar caused by the melting of the snow. I am having the earth removed over the pipe to allow draining.

I am asking you, therefore, to be authorized to spend a sum of approximately $50.00 to timber the pipe over a length of 100 feet which is, in my opinion, the best way of protecting it from freezing.

Your humble servant,

(Signed) A. de la Boissière

Honourable Minister

We, the undersigned, expose what is following:

1--We are living in Pointe-Bleue, Lake St-John, and we were born there.

2--All, we have some children who are at the age of going to school.

3--In our present situation, our children cannot go to school, because we are living too far away. We dare say it is impossible, especially in winter-time, for the roads are full of snow.

4--Almost thirty children are at the age of going to school.

5--We have spoken to our representative in House Of Commune about that, but we have not got an answer.

6--Really we cannot explain why there are some people, influential enough, who are against this thing to get a school, in this part of Pointe-Bleue.

7--Consequently, we ask you to send someone, perfectly independent, in our parish with him may hold an inquiry about this situation, and, after that, if it is possible, to send us a report of this inquiry.

8--In that way, we hope to get justice.

9--And, in advance, we are sure you will grant us rights in order to have an elementary school for our children, situated in the rank "C.B."

We thank you very much, Honourable Minister, for that service:

N.B. It would be much better to send your inspector at Mr Philippe Philippe, Pointe-Bleue.

Prosper Laurier, councillor

Blue Point, July 19, 1937.

Sir,

Following your letter No. 21-1-1, dated July 9, in which you enclosed a petition by the Indians, etc., which I am returning herewith after having underlined in red the names of the residents of Ranges B and C who signed the said petition; I may say that among those who signed three are unmarried and two families are without children.

I am also enclosing a list of the names of 21 children, all of school age, and who live on the said ranges; of these, 5 will not return to school.

The parents of these children own horses and could easily arrange, if they wish to do so, to each in their turn transport their children to the village school during the winter.

As for the suggestion mentioned in your letter of February 10 last, I must say that the majority of the Indian hunters wish that the school be enlarged in order that it may contain a third classroom. I may add that even if, some day, a school should be built on ranges B and C, a third classroom in the village school would nevertheless be necessary.

I believe the cost of enlarging the school should not be more than $500.00, and if you have no objection, the school could be enlarged on the west side, which would not impair its architectural style. I am enclosing herewith a list containing the signatures of Indians who promise to pay for the timber and to furnish the labour. I could have had many more signatures, but many of the Indians have left the village to travel during the summer. I may say that I do not rely overmuch on these promises.

It would be greatly appreciated if this construction work could be completed this summer.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) A. de la Boissière,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ont., Oct. 12, 1938.

Sir:

I beg to submit my inspection report of the Pointe Bleue agency made on October 1st, 2nd & 3rd.

Paint is badly needed for the outside of the school house, as no painting has been done during the past ten years.

The ceiling of each classroom is sagging in the centre and the plaster is damaged. This began to show about three years after the building was finished and has been getting worse every year. For safety I requested Agent to employ a competent man to make repairs needed as soon as possible. The whole cost of this work should not exceed $50.00.

The water from the artesian well is good. It is pumped in tank by gas engine.

Two toilets are placed in cellar for boys and girls and from a moral standpoint this is quite wrong. It would have been very easy to install a toilet for the girls just next to the one used by the teachers upstairs. The expense would be very light and morality would certainly benefit by the change. During class hours, many times every day, children have to go to the toilets in the cellar where the teachers are in their class and there is nobody to supervise the going and coming of the children. Many of these pupils are from twelve to sixteen years of age and over. If my suggestion of having a toilet installed upstairs for the girls were followed up, the cellar toilets would be used by the boys only.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec Inspectorate.
Sir:

I beg to submit my inspection report of the Pointe Bleue agency made on October 1st, 2nd and 3rd.

Upon my visit to the school, I was surprised to notice that all children are using the same cup and what is worse, dip it in a pail hung from the wall to get it filled - against all principles of hygiene.

May I strongly recommend that a small sink be set up in a corner of this entrance hall and a tap connected from the water tank to enable children coming to school with dirty hands to wash them. Also, I would recommend the installation of one automatic drinking fountain on one end of the sink as this would do away with the necessity of using the cup as mentioned above. This is one improvement which could be made with the "Special T.B. Fund".

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec Inspectorate.
Ottawa, Ont., Oct. 12, 1938.

Sir:

I beg to submit my inspection report of the Pointe Bleue agency made on October 1st, 2nd and 3rd.

Over ninety-three pupils have registered at the beginning of the school year, with an average presence of 80 for the first month. These children have never received any special attention as to prevention of T.B. and I sincerely hope that a certain amount will be available from the T.B. Funds to allow the daily distribution of one half pint of milk per day to every child from now to end of school year. Furthermore, may I suggest that a daily dose of Cod Liver Oil be given each child for the winter months. The children need it all, and I hope they will get it.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec Inspectorate.

October 25, 1938.

Dear Sir:

Inspector Thibault, in reporting on his inspection of your Agency for the first three days of October, observes that the school children at your Agency have never received any special attention for the purpose of controlling the spread of tuberculosis among them. You have now a strong tuberculosis organization at Roberval and you should ask Doctor Pinsult to go with you to the head of the sanatorium and discuss what measures should be taken for the control of tuberculosis, not only among the school children, but among the adults of the Pointe Bleue Reserve also. The most usual method to accomplish this is to administer the tuberculin test to all the children and to further examine those found to have a positive reaction.

You would not need to consult the Department further up to this point, but it would be appreciated if you would ask the doctors to give you a report when this has been done, so that the Department may consider...

A. de la Boissiere, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, P.Q.
what further measures can be carried out during the present year.

Mr. Thibault also recommends the issue of a half pint of milk per day to every child during the school year. In another part of his report he says that there are about 100 milking cows on the Reserve. You might discuss this matter also with the doctor and submit to the Department any recommendation you and he might agree upon. The Department would probably authorize the issue of the milk, but thinks that a population with a considerable number of cows ought to be able to supply the milk at fairly low cost, seeing that in many families children would be consuming milk which is already available at home.

Mr. Thibault recommends also that Cod Liver Oil be made available for the children at the school. For many years the Department has urged that this be done and you have only to ask the doctor to prepare requisitions for the oil at the rate of one quart for each pupil. The official standard dose is one teaspoonful twice daily, to be given by the school teachers.

He also recommends that you take charge of a quantity of home remedies such as cough medicines, liniments, and ointments. The Department distributes these medicines widely, but does not wish to set up what may become a sort of free drug store. It is quite willing to supply Cod Liver Oil and the only reason for asking you to make a requisition is to ensure that the teachers are willing to handle it. It would also be quite willing to send a supply of ointment if, for example, there were a widespread outbreak of scabies or impetigo.

Kindly talk all these things over with the doctor and advise the Department what you would like to have done.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Hudson's Bay Company.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. J. THIBAULT,
INSPECTOR OF INDIAN AGENCIES, DATED MARCH 11th, 1939,
ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE POINTE BLEUE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

The school children are still dipping the only drinking cup available into the open water pail, against all principles of hygiene. The suggestion contained in my inspection report of October 12th, 1938, has not been accepted; I had recommended installing a small sink and hygienic drinking faucet, which could be done at very small expense.
Ottawa,
March 20, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his recent inspection of the Pointe Bleue school Inspector Thibault recommends the installation of a small sink. Please let me know what this would cost.

The Inspector also considers that a water container should be supplied. These can be secured at a cost of approximately $5.00 and you may arrange for local purchase.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. de la Boissiere, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.
Monsieur,

Nous nous permettons de vous faire connaître les mesures qui s'imposent le plus pour le moment.

Plusieurs fois vous avez été informé que le plafond des classes baissait de niveau, il nous semble nécessaire d'attirer votre attention sur ce point, car déjà...
il a baisé de deux foisces
nous pouvez juger par vous-
même du danger. Peut-être pour
tirer vous profiter de ces travaux
pour faire remettre à neuf nos
planchers qui sont en aucune
réparation depuis la construc-
tion. Il nous semble que ce
serait pas trop exagéré que de
demander cette dépense après de
ans. Nous espérons que vous
autoriserez M. l'Agent pour
les travaux.

Comme nous aimons à
nous conformer au désir du
département, nous nous effor-
cerons de faire exécuter à nos
frais les travaux domestiques,
mais comme ils sont très
favoris, nous avons pensé de demander la somme de $15.00 pour acheter le matériel nécessaire.

Permettez-nous une demande un peu intéressée peut-être, mais qui nous sera d'une grande utilité pour préparer les cours et autres :

Un stéthoscope de qualité, peut-être en argent ou quelque chose de plus dur, nous serait satisfait.

Dans l'espoir d'une réponse favorable, nous vous prions d'agir sur cette demande respectueusement et de bien vouloir.

Les S.S.H.D. du B.C.

Par Soeur Sainte Jeanne
Blue Point, March 31, 1939.

T.R.L. MacInnes, Esq.,
Secretary.

Sir,

We have informed you on several occasions that the ceiling of the classrooms was sinking, and as it has now sunk 10 inches, you will realize the danger which it presents. It might be a good opportunity also to have our floors rebuilt, as they have never been repaired since the construction of the school. It seems to us that it is not asking too much to have these repairs done after ten years.

We trust that you will give the necessary authority to the Agent in order to have this work done.

In compliance with the wishes expressed by the Department, we instruct our pupils in domestic work, but as they are very poor, we thought of requesting a sum of $15.00 to purchase the required materials.

Further, if you had a used typewriter which you could spare, it would be very useful to us to prepare our examinations, etc.

In the hope that you will consider these requests favourably, we are,

Yours truly,

The Sisters of Notre-Dame du Bon Conseil,

by: Sister Sainte-Jeanne.
Extract from report of School Inspector C.E. Boily on his inspection of the Pointe Bleue Indian day school on April 26, 1939:

The report showed that there were 91 children present on the day of the inspection. The Inspector remarked as follows on his report:

"As I have remarked in preceding reports it is necessary to open a third class room."

"107 pupils enrolled for two instructors is not tolerated in any other school in my inspectorate. It seems to me that the Department should make some effort to improve the situation. I suggest a third teacher."

(Sgd.) C.E. Boiley,
School Inspector.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Sisters in charge of the Pointe Bleue school in which they state that repairs are required to prevent the building from sinking. Please let me have an estimate of the expenditure that would be necessary in this regard. You should understand that our funds are very limited and you should, therefore, forward an estimate only on the work that is absolutely necessary.

I wish also to direct your attention to my letter of March 20 to which no reply has yet been received. An immediate reply is expected.

You may arrange for the purchase of material at a cost not exceeding $15.00 to be used in the domestic science class.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed an account for $233.10 in favour of Mr. René Potvin, merchant of Roberval, Lake St. John, for white lead, "protectus," turpentine, linseed oil, paint, etc., sold in August 1939, for painting the inside and the outside of the Pointe Bleue school.

I was forced to have the ceiling of the school levelled, as the rough cast was badly cracked and was in danger of collapsing. After this work was done the inside of the school was in a bad shape and it was necessary to have it repainted, which entailed extra expenditures. Further, the outside due to wear required much more paint than we had provided for.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant enclosing an account for $235.10 in connection with painting the interior and exterior of the Pointe Bleue school.

In official letter of August 10, 1939, you were authorized to expend an amount of $66.00 for materials for painting this building. On October 6 you forwarded an account for $7.26 covering the cost of nails and linseed oil to be used at the Pointe Bleue school and quoted as your authority official letter of August 10. This latter account was paid and left a balance authorized for painting materials of $58.74.

The Department cannot understand why, without obtaining authority, you exceeded the appropriation to such an extent as shown by the account just received. I think you will realize that if Indian Agents were allowed to exceed their authority in this manner it would be impossible for the Department to keep any control of expenditure. Under the circumstances I am inclined to feel that the only procedure that we can take is to pay $58.74 on the amount and allow you to pay the balance yourself.

Yours truly,

Mr. A. de la Boissiere,
Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, Que.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Inspection of Pointe Bleue Agency.

I beg to submit a report of my inspection at Pointe Bleue, Quebec, in the course of March last.

SCHOOL

I was pleased to note that most of my suggestions of March 1939, had been complied with, except the "automatic drinking faucet". It was well to have an ordinary faucet and small sink installed to prevent dipping drinking cup into water-tap, but the end is not achieved when over seventy pupils are using the "one cup". Individual cups, bowls, etc would be rather costly, but a special faucet - requiring no cup - would supply all required water to drink at any time - easy - clean and hygienic. If we are taking any steps to stop T.B. increasing on this reserve, we should, in my opinion, give the children the least chance for contamination.

Cod Liver Oil has been distributed regularly, and results can be seen in the healthy appearance of the children.

The suggestion to repair ceilings of the two classrooms was made in my inspection report of October 1938. I had estimated the cost of such repairs at about $50.00, judging from appearance at that time; however, nothing was done until July or August 1939, when the ceiling kept lowering all the time, and was then a terrible menace. I have interviewed one of the men who worked on the repairs, and he informed me that in one classroom the ceiling had come down eleven inches, while in the other room it was down nine inches. Whoever was supervising the construction surely slept on his job, to let a contractor get away with such fault of construction. Due to conditions being worse when repairs were made than when seen it in 1938, the cost of repairs was higher; the plaster had to be repaired; the whole ceiling had to be as well as all the walls, re-decorated in both classrooms, as scaffolding had somewhat touched the walls also. There appears to be a balance of $167.10 for materials due on this repair, and after seeing the work done I feel that no undue cost was added, and I recommend the payment of the said balance of $167.10.

No more paint was required for outside work, as the woodwork had become spongy, having received no paint since its construction in 1927-28. No house owner could expect to keep his property in good shape if painted every ten years, or if he does, he must expect to use a lot more paint, besides the depreciation of the lumber. A professional house builder and painter would probably not make such a difference in his estimates, but our Agent and even myself are not experts in the matter.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec.

Pointe Bleue, April 12, 1944.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

At a meeting of the Tribu Montagnaise of the Pointe Bleue Reserve, held on April 10, at the Indian school, and at which were present the Chief and Three Councillors, and also a fair number of the Tribe, following resolution was submitted to the Council.

It was moved by Mr. Joseph Raphael, seconded by Mr. Joseph Courtois, that a request be made to the General Superintendent of Indian Affairs that a school be built in ranges B and C of Pointe Bleue, considering that the children of said ranges have to walk a distance of two to two and a half miles in order to reach the village school.

Chef.

I beg to report that the water from the Artesian well at the school tastes of gasoline, due to the fact that, the engine being set up over the well, gasoline is seeping in.

During a visit by Mr. Thibault, Inspector of the Reserves, we examined the location of the engine and it was ascertained that it would be necessary to move it.

I therefore ask you to kindly authorize me to pay out $50 to have this change made, pay for labour, buy a chain and construct a room for the engine so that it may be safe from the children.

Ottawa, October 3, 1945.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON POINTE BLEUE INDIAN AGENCY

SCHOOL

I visited the school on September 21st and found that seventy-five children were registered.

The junior Class has 47 seats with forty-six pupils in Grades I, II and III; the senior Class has 30 seats with 29 pupils in Grades IV, V, VI, VII, VIII.

These children are all residing on the reserve and another family with 5 children of school age is expected back.

One might imagine what a teacher has to put up with in a class of 47 juniors when windows are closed in winter and the place heated; ordinary ventilation is not sufficient in such cases. It is agreed that the Family Allowance has something to do with the increased and more regular attendance.

Since the location of the gas engine, used for pumping the water, was changed, the water can now be used from drinking, as the gasoline infiltration in the well is done away with, there is yet a very slight taste which will gradually disappear in time.

The school grounds are gradually sloping towards the railway fence, and I strongly recommend that a start be made towards leveling the same, this fall if at all possible, about one hundred dollars would help to start the improvement. As it is now, with larger attendance and older boys, there should be better playgrounds available for ball playing. Rather Lajeunesse is greatly interested in having all Indian boys take part in open air games. At this time, I have been told that a football would be most welcomed by the boys, if at all available and meets with your approval. Soft ball and bat could also be used, if sent now, if sent in care of our Indian Agent, Mr. A. de la Boissiere.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Hudson's Bay Company.

Inside of school should be redecorated. Plaster will have to be repaired. Note the finish coat of plaster is very thin and peels off quite easily.

The heating should be inspected by a competent furnace expert. The furnace appears to be large enough to heat the school rooms comfortably. Yet it has been necessary to install a stove in the classroom on the north side. It is my opinion that if the hot air registers were increased and placed differently the building could be heated without much difficulty.

Water system. The sewer pipe froze close to the wall under the foundation last winter which meant that it would not drain the toilets. This caused considerable inconvenience. It may be that the septic tank, which has not been serviced since it was constructed, should be opened up and overhauled.

Desks (school) are old and have been painted several times. New ones should be purchased. Suggest that the Agent be requested to submit a requisition stating the number and the size required.

À une assemblée du Conseil de la Tribu Montagnaise de la réserve de Pointe Bleue, tenue le 27 décembre courant à l'école indienne de la dite réserve, à laquelle assemblée assistait le Chef, 3 Conseillers et plusieurs membres de la tribu, la proposition suivante a été soumise au Conseil.

Il a été proposé par M. Gabriel Hurtmess, secondé par M. Joseph Raphael, qu'une demande soit faite au Secrétaire Général pour que les écoliers qui dinent à l'école parce qu'ils demeurent loin, aient de la soupe aux frais du Département et demande aussi que les enfants aient une classe de couture.

Chef, Gabriel Hurtmess

Dear Sir,

At a meeting of the Council of the Montagnais Tribe of Pointe Bleue Reserve, on December 27 instant, at the Indian school of said Reserve, to which were present the Chief, three councillors and several members of the Tribe the following proposition was submitted to the Council.

Proposed by Mr. Gabriel Kurtness, seconded by Mr. Joseph Raphael, that a request be sent to the Superintendent General in order that the pupils who lunch at school because they are living too far be given soup at the Department's expense, and also that the children receive sewing courses.

That proposition was unanimously approved by the Council.

Je dois vous dire que le canal d'égout à l'école indienne de Pointe Bleue est depuis 3 ou 4 jours gelé au point qu'il est hors de service. Le tuyau n'ayant pas assez de pente les déchets s'y sont accumulés et ont gelés; quant au puisard il est en bonne condition.

Comme ce canal est chaque hiver une cause de sérieux ennui, il faudrait nécessairement qu'au cours de l'été il soit creusé plus profondément et comme le roc n'est pas loin il faudra même miner.

D'après les essais que j'ai fait je sais par expérience qu'il est inutile de tenter de le dégeler, il fait trop froid et il recommencera à geler.

Je demande donc l'autorisation de faire construire des cabinets d'aisance à l'extérieur de l'école, ce qui rendra toujours service quand il y aura quelque chose de défectueux dans ceux de l'intérieur.

La main-d'œuvre et le matériel de construction coûteront environ $90.00. Quant au prix que cela coutera pour le creusage du canal je vous en reparlerai ce printemps.

Agent des Indiens.
Pointe Bleue, January 31st, 1947.

Department of Mines and Resources,
Branch of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

Gentlemen:

I must inform you that the sewer drain of the Indian school at Pointe Bleue has been frozen for three or four days and that it is out of service. Since the pipe is not sufficiently inclined, refuse has accumulated and frozen; as for the cesspool, it is in good shape.

Since this drain is the cause of serious worries each winter, it should necessarily be dug further next summer and as the rock is not far down, blasting will even be necessary.

According to the tests I made, I know through experience that it is useless to try and thaw it; it is too cold and it will freeze again.

Therefore, I am asking for the permission to have water closets built outside the school, which will always be handy when something goes wrong in those inside.

Labour and building material will cost approximately $90.00. As for the cost of digging the drain further down, I shall take this up with you again in the spring.

Yours truly,

(SGD) A. de la Boissière,
INDIAN AGENT.

Faisant suite à votre lettre No.21-1-5, (N.T.) datée du 15 juillet courant, permettez-moi de vous dire que selon l'entente avec M. Doucet j'ai fait découvrir le canal d'égout ainsi que le puisard de l'école de la réserve de Pointe Bleue, et j'ai fait inspecter le dit canal par MM. Binet et Frère, de Roberval.

Je vous inclus un estimé au montant de $350.00 de MM. Binet & Frère, plombiers, pour la fourniture et la pose d'un tuyau d'égout en fonte sur une longueur de 125 pds pour remplacer le système d'égout actuel qui est un tuyau en bois et qui est percé à différents endroits. La dite école est bâtie depuis 20 ans.

Je vous demande en plus du montant de l'estimé, un montant de $200.00 pour payer le salaire des hommes qui ont découvert le dit canal d'égout et le recouvrir après y avoir transporter du sable et du brin de scie pour protéger le tuyau contre la gelée. Il faut aussi remplacer la couverture du puisard laquelle est pourrie. Ceci demandera 30 morceaux de bois de cèdre de 13 pds, ce qui coutera $15.00 pour le bois. Il faudra aussi 50 sacs de ciment à .90 le sac, pour en étendre partout dans la cave parce que l'eau s'y infiltre. J'ai déboursé $54.50 pour payer le salaire des hommes qui ont creusé le dit canal.

Agent des Indiens.
Pointe Bleue, July 26, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Pursuant to your letter No. 21-1-5 (WT 1) dated July 16th instant, allow me to state that according to the understanding with Mr. Doucet, I have had the sewer canal and also the school cesspool uncovered, and I got the said canal inspected by Messrs. Binet & Frère, of Roberval.

I am sending you enclosed an estimate amounting to $360 from Messrs. Binet & Frère, plumbers, for furnishing and laying a cast-iron sewer pipe on a length of 125 feet to replace the present sewer system which is a wooden pipe that is pierced in many places. The said school was built 20 years ago.

I am asking you also, in addition to the amount of the above estimate, the sum of $200 to pay the salary of the men who have uncovered the said sewer canal and who will recover it after having transported sand and sawdust to protect the pipe against frost. It is also necessary to replace the cesspool cover which has rotted. This will require 30 pieces of cedar wood 13 feet long which will cost $15. Fifty bags of cement at 90 cents per bag will also be needed. This cement will be spread in the cellar because the water comes up (infiltrates). I disbursed $54.50 to pay the salary of the men who dug the said canal.

Yours truly,

A. de la Boissière
Indian agent.

Pointe Bleue, Oct. 3, 1947.

Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Allow me to state that from the division line of Roberval to lot No. 24, range A, there are about fifteen Indian children of school age who are as far from the village school as those who live in ranges B. & C. of Pointe Bleue.

The parents of those children ask that their children be brought to the village school in a conveyance as is the case with the others living in the ranges.

The conveyance such as that of last winter, will cost $125.00 and Mr. David Courtois, Indian, living on the borderline of Pointe Bleue-Roberval, is ready to transport them for $60 per month.

Considering the long distance that those children have to cover to come to the village school, I support this request.

Yours truly,

A. de la Boissière,
Indian agent.

Mr. A. de la Boissiere, Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, P...,

we have your letter of the 3rd instant with reference to driving certain children to the Pointe Bleue Indian Day School.

Officials of the Departments of Education throughout Canada agree that pupils under ten years of age can walk two miles each way daily and children over ten years can walk three miles each way daily.

We understand that the children to whom you refer in your letter reside within two miles of the Pointe Bleue School and that they can go to school along the main highway which is kept ploughed during the winter.

The Department is, therefore, not prepared to provide any funds for their transportation.

January 22, 1948.

Mr. A. de la Boissiere, Indian Agent,
Pointe Bleue, P.Q.

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant, I regret that owing to lack of funds it is not possible to authorize at the present time an amount of $50.00 for the purchase of dark cloth to be used on the windows in the classrooms at the Pointe Bleue School during the showing of motion pictures.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Pointe Bleue, January 8, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

In order to give the school children of Pointe Bleue a chance of seeing educational motion pictures, the Oblate Fathers of Pointe Bleue asked me if the Department of Indian Affairs would help them by furnishing an amount of $50 for the purchase of dark cloth for the windows of the classrooms and for the electrical installation.

The electricity will be fed and furnished free of charge by the Oblate monastery Delco, and the reverend Fathers will also supply the films gratuitously.

I therefore recommend the Oblate Fathers request.

A. de la Boissière,
Indian agent.

Memorandum:

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Training.

When I visited Pointe Bleue Reserve in June, I asked an insulation firm from St. Joseph d'Alma to send in a tender for the insulation of the Pointe Bleue Indian Agency house.

Last winter I visited the same Reserve and the two-classroom School. At the time of this inspection I was told that this School was very cold and needed insulation. To date, I do not believe you have received this tender, but should you receive it, would you kindly give it serious consideration. If you decide to concur in this, would you kindly communicate with Indian Agent A. de la Boissiere, Pointe Bleue, P.Q.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School, Pointe Bleue Indian Agency, Province of Quebec, Electoral District of Lake St. John-Roberval.

Both Regional Supervisor Gendron and Indian Agent de la Boissiere have reported that the Pointe Bleue School is very cold in winter and recommend that the building be insulated.

Segueney Insolation Enr., St. Joseph d'Alma, P.Q., have offered to insulate the building for $921.60. This is a two room school and the firm agree to insulate both the walls and the ceiling with mineral wool insulation of a minimum thickness of four inches.

Director.

Memorandum:

Pointe Bleue, October 29, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Mr Chrysostome Launiere, Indian of Pointe Bleue Reserve, who is looking after the transportation of the pupils to the Indian School, complained that the amount of $60.00 per month is not sufficient for such work.

Besides he asked me to help him with food and clothing........

Mr Launiere would like to receive at least $100.00 per month for the transportation of the pupils; for my part I believe that $60.00 per month is very satisfactory.

According to the informations received, Mr Launiere is complaining without reason.

He receives $60.00 for transportation of the pupils
$25.00 from Family Allowances
$11.00 a week for milk sold outside

Moreover, during the summer he has worked from time to time and he sold firewood.

I have refused to give any assistance to Mr Launiere on account of the reasons mentioned above; I understand that he is one of the (Rough and Tough Indian of this reserve) asking help without any serious reason.

I let the decision to your Department, but myself I do not recommend an increase of his salary for the transportation of pupils.

Edgar Arsenault, Supt,
Pointe Bleue.

Cher Monsieur l'Agent:

Auriez-vous l'obligeance de soumettre à votre département notre demande pour une augmentation du loyer de la salle servant de classe provisoirement, en raison du manque de local pour tous les élèves de la réserve.

À sa dernière visite, Monsieur Gendron, inspecteur des agences après inspection de ce local restauré au cours de l'été dernier, a autorisé que cette demande soit faite au département par l'entremise de Monsieur l'Agent.

En raison d'une absence de quelques semaines, nous n'avons pu le faire avant aujourd'hui.

Nous croyons donc que $20.00 par mois, à partir de septembre, serait considéré comme convenable pour Nous et le Département. Je vous serais donc reconnaissant si vous donniez vous-même les détails que vous jugerez nécessaires sur les conditions actuelles de ce local; dimensions, apparence, électricité, conditions qui motivent notre demande.

Agreez, cher monsieur, mes meilleurs sentiments.

Votre tout dévoué,

Rev. Pere Aram Rthier, O.M.I., Sup.
Pointe Bleue, Dec. 9, 1948.

Indian Affairs Agency,
Pointe Bleue,
Roberval county,

Dear Sir,

Would you kindly submit to your department our request for an increase of rent of the room used temporarily as a classroom on account of the lack of space for all the pupils of the reservation.

On his last visit, Mr. Gendron, Inspector of agencies, after inspecting this room which was renovated last summer, authorized this request being made to the Department through the agent's offices.

Owing to the fact that I was away for a few weeks, I was unable to send this request before today.

I think that $20 per month, from the month of September, would be satisfactory to us and to the Department. I should be grateful if you would personally give the details that you will judge necessary on the present conditions of this place: dimensions, appearance, electric power, conditions which motivate our request.

Yours truly,

Rvd. Father Aram Ethier, OMI,
Superior.

Pointe Bleue, Dec. 10, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Attached please find copy of a letter received from Rev. Father Aram Ethier, Superior of Monastere des Oblats of Pointe Bleue.

This letter is self explanatory and for my part I would recommend a rent of $20.00 per month commencing in September.

The local secured by the Father for a class for the indian pupils is a public hall completely repaired last summer.

The building is 34½ ft by 28½ ft, giving a stand of 13 ft wide for the teacher's desk.

The hall has been completely painted inside this summer and moreover the father secures the electric lights from his delco plan. It is well lighted, clean, large enough for the number of pupils, well heated, and secures a very comfortable class for the Indians.

Considering the repairs and improvement made last summer on the hall, it is only just and fair that an amount of $20.00 at least be paid for the rent of that local.

Edgar Arsenault, Supt.
Pointe Bleue Agency.
December 20, 1948.

Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Pointe Bleue, P.Q.

In view of your letter of the 10th instant, the Department will allow a rental of $20.00 a teaching month from September 1st, 1948 for the building used as a second classroom at the Point Bleue School.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF INDIAN EDUCATION

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School

There is an enrolment of 20 pupils in grades V, VI, VII, and IX under the direction of the senior teacher. There are 33 pupils in grades III and IV, and 49 in grades I and II. Grades III and IV are combined and are taught in the parish hall which is quite unsatisfactory as a classroom. It is being used as an emergency.

It is recommended to build a classroom, plan 865. A male teacher would take charge of the senior boys. According to the present enrolment there would be approximately 20 pupils. Grades VIII and IX should attend provincial High Schools. There will be 6 in this category next year. The principal has been instructed to notify the Department as soon as the final standing of these pupils is known.

There seems to be some misunderstanding between Robervaal and the reserve. There is not here the cooperation that is noticed at Lorette, Pierreville, and other localities which now show a great deal of goodwill toward the Indians. This misunderstanding seems to be caused principally by ignorance of Government policy on the part of the authorities in Robervaal. In order that activities on the reserve be successful I believe that this misunderstanding should be cleared as soon as possible.

Respectfully submitted,

A. J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Vocational Education.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School,
Pointe Bleue Indian Agency, Quebec.

We are erecting a one-room school with attached teacher's residence at the above school. The materials have been purchased through the Departmental Purchasing Agent and in reply to our memorandum of July 5, approval was given for the employment of Mr. Amedee Harvey, of Roberval, as foreman.

We have now received the following quotations:

I ELECTRICITY.

(a) Alfred Lavoie, Roberval, Que.
Wiring only .................. $700.00

(b) O. Electrique, Inc., Roberval, Que.
per Raymond Ouellet
Wiring and fixtures .............. 1,417.00

(c) Romeo Trottier, Roberval, Que.
Wiring and fixtures ............... 1,399.83

(d) Le Chauffage Moderne Enrg.,
St. Felicien, Que.
per B. Savard, St. Felicien, Que. .......... 1,052.90

Mr. Doucet, of this Division, who visited Pointe Bleue last week, recommends the acceptance of the tender of
Romeo Trottier, in an amount of $1,399.83 as he is reported to be a reliable man and Mr. Savard's tender appears incomplete. I attach a letter which we have received from the Indian Agent.

II HEATING.

(a) Le Chauffage Moderne Enrg. St. Felicien, Que.
per Raymond Savard ........... $2,300.00

This quotation is for hot water while our plans and specifications call for Forced Hot Air. Mr. Savard did not wish to quote on the latter.

(b) Brunet & Frere Roberval, Que. .......... 2,225.00

These were the only two quotations that Mr. Doucet could obtain and we recommend the acceptance of the lower tender.

III PLUMBING.

(a) Le Chauffage Moderne Enrg. St. Felicien,
per Raymond Savard ........... 1,995.00

(b) Brunet & Frere Roberval, Que. .......... 1,775.00

Mr. Doucet was only able to obtain the above two tenders and we recommend acceptance of the lower tender.

The construction of this building is proceeding and it is necessary to arrange for the electricity, heating and plumbing at the earliest possible date. It would be appreciated if the Minister would approve the recommendations made in this memorandum.

Attention: Mr J.A. Doucet.

Re: Erection Indian Day School Pointe Bleue.

Following our phone conversation regarding the work re erection of the Indian School, as already stated, the outside work and also the septic tank and outlet are completed.

The inside is also well advanced; all the partitions made and they have started today to place the gyprock; we did not receive yet all the gyprock required, but we expect it anytime.

The plumbing is completed except the fittings; for the electricity they have completed the wiring.

Mr. Laberge who has drilled two wells on the reserve here has examined the well in the old school, and he does not recommend to clean it, as according to him, it would be useless because it would not give any good result. He claims the same thing happened near Montreal few years ago, and they tried to clean the well, but the water had still the same smell and taste. He suggested the only solution would be to drill another well and plug the old one with cement.

The daylight is getting scarce in the morning and at night and of course we would need some light for the work of the carpenters inside; we had thought to use gas lanterns, or aladin lamps, but it is more or less commendable on account of the danger for fire and moreover, as the carpenters have to move from one room to the other and it is not possible to carry the lanterns each time.
I have discussed the matter with Rev. Father Ethier, and I believe it would be possible to use their Delco light for a very reasonable cost per day; it is easy to have the connection from the hall it is near the new school.

As the furnace is not yet arrived, we have been obliged to organize a stove in the kitchen to heat the second floor where men are working; and it is necessary to have another system (stove or oil furnace) in the basement room; it is too cold and too damp without fire; Mr. Harvey has been requested to enquire about the cost of a small oil furnace; I believe it is the best system we could install in the basement, as we need heat during the night on account of the fresh paint. Mr. Binet does not expect the big furnace before the end of December.

At the end, I think an oil furnace would be more economic; with an ordinary wood stove, we would be obliged to buy the wood at $5.00 per cord, and pay a man during the night to keep the fire going.

Hope these few informations will help you to settle the question.

Your visit will be appreciated.

Edgar Arsenault,
Supt.
Pointe Bleue Agency.

We are obliged to return your Credit Voucher # 506 as the Treasury Branch will not accept it in the manner in which it has been prepared.

Treasury Branch officials point out that in many cases on the Labour Return form the foreman signed for payments that were presumably made to those who were working on the building.

May I impress on you the fact that when preparing Credit Vouchers accounting for advances forwarded to you, each person to whom a payment has been made should sign the Labour Return form.

This is the second Credit Voucher that we have been obliged to return to you and it is hoped that you will obtain the proper signatures on voucher # 506 and return it at your earliest convenience.

You should also keep in mind the instructions contained in this letter when preparing future Credit Vouchers for other advances that you have received.

Attention: Mr. J. A. Doucet, Supt., M.T. Division.

At your last visit we have discussed the question of heating system for the New Indian Day School.... We have organized the oil furnace in the basement, and according to the opinion of Mr. Binet and Harvey, the heat secured would be sufficient to prevent the frost of the water system and keep the building at a temperate warmth; but the heat is not sufficient if the Nurse occupies the kitchen and living room as dispensary.

There is no opening communicating directly from the basement and the kitchen, and of course it would be too cold for a person to remain there.

If those two rooms are given to the Nurse, an other oil furnace is required to heat the two rooms; the cost is about $50.00 for the purchase, plus the cost for the necessary oil.

As the second oil furnace is not necessary for us, you may make the necessary arrangements with the Department concerned for the payment of the furnace and oil if you so desire.

I am waiting for a written authority before giving the two rooms at the disposal of Nurse Levesque. Report on the matter has already been forwarded to the Dept. concerned.

I would be pleased to be advised of the decision taken regarding the furnace and the two rooms for Nurse Levesque.

Edgar Arsenault, Supt.,

Re: Pointe Bleue Indian Day School

The Department finds it necessary to again return your Credit Voucher No. 503 covering labour for the weeks ending August 25th, September 1st, September 8th, September 15th, September 22nd and September 29th, 1949.

If you review this Voucher you will note that in different places you have deducted income tax but you have not taken credit for it. In addition, you have not given any evidence either by cheque number or receipt, of the money having been remitted to the Income Tax Department.

In several cases on the Credit Voucher the payment has not been receipted by the person entitled to receive a payment. Presumably, money was given to someone else to give to such worker. Have you any definite evidence that the man entitled to the money received it?

If workers are not present when payment is being made, the amount due them should be omitted from the paylist containing the names of those who were present and signed the paylist for themselves.

Cheques should then be issued and mailed to those entitled to payment but who were not present when you were paying the others. A separate Credit
Voucher should then be prepared and forwarded to us stating the number of the cheque. You should keep in mind that the Auditor General requires definite evidence that payment has been made to the person to whom any payment is due. The only manner in which this can be obtained is to have his signature on the paylist or his signature on a cheque for the amount owing to him.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
