Pointe Bleue, February 4, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief E.D.

I wish to draw your attention on the fact that we have not yet received any authority for the purchase and installation of the sump pump for the new Indian Day School.

Mr. Binet advised that he does not take any responsibility if damages are caused by water in the basement of the School because he did not receive any instruction regarding the matter.

During the heavy rains we have had in January, the level of the water comes up to 4 inches from the basement floor. Then, we may expect that in the spring the basement could be flooded if no proper equipment is installed to evacuate the water contained in the reservoir made for that purpose.

I understand that the electricity is not yet organized in the reserve, but I wonder if it would not be advisable to have the sump pump installed immediately in order to have it when the electricity will be available. In the meantime, I believe it would be urgent to have instructions from you to install an ordinary pump on the reservoir, in order to prevent flooding in the basement.

We could arrange to have that pump connected with the outlet drain pipe. I have a spare pump that could be used for the purpose and we would need a certain length of hose for the connection.

Your immediate instructions would be appreciated.

Eugène Arsenault, Supt.

Memorandum:

Mr. Dupont
Indian Education Division.

Re: Electrification - Pointe Bleue Indian Reserve.

Mr. Arsenault was instructed in letter of June 13, 1949 as follows:

1. If the Saguenay Power Company has expropriation powers they should:
   (a) furnish a plan showing the proposed position of their line on the Indian Reserve.
   (b) obtain the written consent of the Indians whose lands will be affected and pay them compensation.

2. If the Company has not expropriation powers in addition to the plan and consent of the individual Indians a band resolution will have to be secured.

NOTE: We informed Mr. Arsenault in the same letter that the Company could proceed to construct the line as soon as they secured the consent of the individual Indians, on the understanding that they would supply the plan as soon as possible afterwards.

Mr. Allan wrote on Oct. 26th to Mr. Arsenault giving him the same information as was contained in our letter of June 13th, and stated that when the company forwarded the information requested a permit would issue to them permitting them to run their line across the reserve.

Apparently Mr. Arsenault had several interviews with the company and was asked by them to supply the following:

1. Secure from Indian Affairs authority for the company to set up and maintain its line.
Note: This Mr. Arsenault could not do until the Company had secured and forwarded documents from the individual Indians, as asked for in 1 (a), and forwarded the plan asked for in 1 (b). However, as mentioned the permit could not issue until the plan was received, but once the consent of the Indians was secured and compensation paid the Company would not be hindered in the construction of the line. In theory the plan is required, but in actual practice I understand that the electric power companies are allowed to construct the line and furnish the plan later.

2. Supply the company with a plan indicating the location of the proposed customers. (There does not appear to be any reason why Mr. Arsenault could not have attended to this).

3. Supply the company with a list of the owners of lots and sites. (Mr. Arsenault could also have supplied this information)

It would appear from a letter addressed by the Company to Mr. Arsenault that Mr. Tellier and Mr. Freulix of the Saguenay Power Co. met you (they refer to a representative of the school construction, whom I presume to be you) and you offered to supply the information requested by the company, which information was to be supplied by December 1949.

In view of the fact that it is of interest to secure electricity for the school as well as for the reserve, it would be appreciated if you would follow the matter up. We do not know from the information on file what steps Mr. Arsenault has taken, nor whether the company has secured the consent of the Indians.

I may add that Mr. Arsenault appears to have handled the whole matter in an incompetent way, and in his letter of Nov. 16th, which I would suggest that you read and which was addressed to the Provincial Electricity Board, Mr. Arsenault accuses the company of "neglect or ill will", and speaks of seeking for help from people in high quarters, namely the Board. His letter is not tasteful to say the least.

May we leave the matter in your hands?

W.J.F. Pratt,
General Executive Assistant.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 27 ultimo I beg to say that I do not approve the change of teacher that the council has made. According to my view, Miss Evans is well able to teach these children for some time yet.

When I have visited the school I found everything there well kept, the scholars answered well in French and English, and have also the advantage to be taught in their own language.

Some complaints have been made to me such as the teacher is too fond and children have become very much out of order. At this juncture the teacher had done her duty.

It is also very unpopular for the new council to ask the dismissed teacher belonging to the opposite party. It will certainly cause ill feeling.

I did explain all these things to the council who appear to understand for a moment and then a big talk ensued in silence which I did not understand and they finally decided she had to go on which I said no more and left it to your decision. My opinion is that it is better to keep her one year more, may be within that we may carry things to have better which would teach girls some keeping sewing etc., etc. I will explain my views in another letter when I get suspension granted.

Sir,

In reply to those paragraphs of the Resolutions adopted by the Council of the Restigouche Band at the meeting held on the 25th instant, I beg to say:

Re Micmacs of Ste. Anne de Restigouche:

Sir:-

Amongst much information received was a statement from the Chief's brother Thomas Isaac that some intoxicating liquor addressed to Chief Isaac Isaac had been seen in Campbellton freight sheds in June last. He was very evidently actuated by anything but kind motives in making this statement, and handed me at the same time a letter from a woman named Maggie Marocque who bears a bad reputation attacking Mary Isaac the reserve school teacher in what appeared to be a very scurrilous manner. Mrs. Larocque is the woman who was in gaol on July 19th last when the men confined with her broke out and was at that time convicted and fined some $27.00.

There was no doubt that these attacks upon the Chief and his daughter proceeded from the worst element upon the reserve, and were directed against the best. I spoke to the Chief about them and he stated that on the occasion of his daughter's marriage last summer he did get in, and use at the wedding a case of porter; that he never then, nor at any other time sold any sort of intoxicant, and that he was not aware that giving porter to his guests was an offence. He said also that the attack upon his daughter was absolutely unfounded and sprang entirely from the spite of a thoroughly bad woman who, he regretted to say, was his niece.

I accepted these explanations believing them from what I knew, and heard, of the parties concerned to be quite true; and put the Chief right as to his belief in the propriety of giving guests porter. In any case where I was assuming the responsibility

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Pitre was instructed to consult with the Public School Inspector with a view to obtaining the services of a duly qualified teacher to succeed Miss Isaacs in the Restigouche school after the summer holidays. He reports that he has complied with the Department's directions and that Mr Inspector Cote informs him that he will communicate with the Department on the subject.

In another letter on this subject the Agent states that as the new teacher will most probably be a white person, it will be necessary to make suitable provision for lodging, as there is no convenient boarding place on the reserve and the boarding houses off the reserve are too far distant.

There are over 75 children of school age on this reserve and last year they had a total enrollment of 44 with an average attendance of 34.

The Department has not made a practice of providing houses for teachers in the Province of Quebec and there are no funds specially available for this purpose. If, however, the Indians are to obtain the full benefit of a school, the teacher should
reside with them. The Agent in his annual report says that the houses are clean and I do not see why a teacher should not be able to make himself comfortable with one of the progressive members of the band.

It would be well for the Agent to inform the prospective teacher of what he may expect to put up with if he receives the appointment. The salary attached to this school is only $200.00.
The Indian Agent informed me that the term of my teaching will end the 31st instant instead of 30th Sept next. I do not see why I was not allowed to teach the full term. When I first began teaching it was in October and why should I not finish the term only in September quarter?

Respectfully Yours,

Mary Isaac

The Petition of the undersigned Indians of the Indian Reserve of
St. Anne de Restigouche in the County of Bonaventure and Province

Humbly Sheweth

That your Petitioners have lived on the Indian Reserve aforesaid for
many years and are desirous of the remaining without having their
Reserve invaded by white people more than is absolutely necessary
for our interests and benefit.

That we fear if once the reserve is thrown open to white people our
band of Indians will be entirely broken up and the remnants of our
people scattered.

That we are at present living in peace and contentment on our reserve
and for years past our school has been taught to our satisfaction by
Mary Isaac one of our number and under her instructions many
of the young Indians and squaws are able to read and write and some
of them have acquired a fair education.

That it has lately been announced by our priest that in future our
school will be taught by nuns.

That we are opposed to this change for the following reasons:

(1) It necessitates the building of a convent which means a further
burden on us. (2) It means that our children's education will be
mostly French to which we are opposed because nearly all our business
relations are with the English, and what our people need is a good
practical English Education. (3) It means the bringing into our reserve
more white people and the gradual obliteration of our tribe.

We therefore humbly request that you will be pleased to prevent
the introduction of the nuns into our Reserve and as in duty bound
will ever pray.

Dated July 20th, 1908.

OTTAWA, 24th July, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the application made by Mr Agent Pitre for a grant to assist in putting up a residence for the new teacher of the Restigouche school, addressed to Mr Marcellin, M.P., and by him forwarded to the Department, I beg to say that these Indians have no funds from which a grant could be made and there is no other money available for the purpose and Mr Agent Pitre was so informed on the 3rd ultimo.

There is a great deal in what the Agent says about the difficulty of obtaining suitable accommodation for a white teacher on the reserve, but the same difficulty is experienced in connection with all Indian day schools and it is only in very exceptional cases where the Department has made a grant for this purpose. Where accommodation has been provided, the funds have been furnished by the Indians, and the teacher's dwelling is the property of the Band. In this case the reverend Fathers are going to erect a dwelling on their own land near the school house, which will be in the nature of a convent and where the Sister appointed to take charge of the Indian school will reside, and it towards the erection of this building that the Agent wishes the Department to contribute.

The schoolhouse is the property of the
Government and if the Department decides to furnish a teacher's dwelling it should be Government property, as it is not certain that the Sisters will always have charge of this school. A petition has reached the Department today protesting against the appointment of the Sisters as teachers, which bears the names of the Chief, two Councillors and sixty-nine members of the Band. The chief objection against the Sisters is the claim that the teaching would be wholly in French, while the Indians say that nearly all their business relations are with the English and that what their people need is a good practical English education.

No mention is made by Mr Pitre of the sum the Department is expected to contribute and we have no estimates to show what a separate teacher's dwelling would cost. The present schoolhouse is an old frame building put up about 45 years ago and it is a question whether it would be worth altering to provide lodging for a teacher.

Sir:

Investigation.

Several complaints having been made against the Sisters of the Holy Rosary, who teach in this Indian school at Restigouche, I invited, after the examination, all the persons interested to meet in the school parlor in order that an investigation might be held. There were present the teaching nuns, Father Pacifique, curé of the mission, Father Robert, Mr. Pitre, agent, the Indian chief and the parents who had complaints to make.

After more than 3 hours' talk with witnesses, etc., the complaintants admitted that they had been deceived by false reports, and that these teachers, the Sisters of the Holy Rosary, deserved all their confidence.

I gave them some advice in regard to the course that they ought to follow on such occasions, that is to say, to report to the curé of the mission, the Reverend Father Pacifique.

Although I am not in charge of this mission, I believe under the circumstances this investigation has done a great deal of good and has led to tranquillity and confidence in the midst of these people.

I have, &c.,
Sgd. J.E. Marquis,

The attendance should be much better. The chief reasons for lack of attendance are the long distance the pupils have to walk to come to school, the want of proper clothes sometimes and also the carelessness of the parents and the idleness of the children.

I suggest that some reliable person be paid to bring the distant children to school in the morning and bring them back home after school hours during the winter months, that another reliable person be paid to hunt up the truants and have them go to school.

Could not the Department assure certain rewards for the attendance of pupils, for the progress they make? I think it would be advisable and it would be a means of making these Indian schools a great success. I gave as a reward to the most deserving pupils of each grade the sum of $2.50 in all. They seemed to be overjoyed.

I visited also the domestic science department. I was surprised to see how the pupils work. A few articles of general use have been made but I regret to say that the allowance of $6.00 a month to buy the necessary articles for this department is not at all sufficient. I would suggest that a sum of at least $15.00 a month be paid to the Sisters so that they may buy the goods they need to make a success of this art department. The clothes, stockings, mitts, underwear worked by the pupils would be distributed then to the poorest families. Thus out of this department, there would be two results, learn the pupils to work out their own clothes and provide poor Indian families with a few clothes.

On visiting the building, I remarked that there was a nice, spacy room intended for a kitchen, but I am sorry to say that there are no stove, nor utensils, nothing at all to have this department go. Sir:

In reference to your letter, No. 26-1-1, of the 25th January, 1921, I regret that I have to say that the correspondence which you have received concerning the instruction given at the school of this reserve is not only exaggerated but is also absolutely false.

First: The children of the Indians of this reserve do not desire to educate themselves either in French or in English, and the parents do not seem to appreciate education, as they do not seem to care to send their children to school. The attendance is certainly not what it should be, the parents do not see to it and we have no officer in charge to look over it, as the constable of the reserve used to do when we had one.

Secondly: For the last two years no instruction is given in French at this school, and that is what is regrettable, but the Indians did not want it and it was not imposed on them.

Third: All the instruction which is given in your school of Restigouche is given in English with the help of the Indian idioms when necessary.

Fourth: The teachers employed in your school speak English and give the instruction in English. Sister Mary of St. Brigitte, whose family name is "Romney," is Irish by her family and English is her mother tongue. Sister Mary of St. Joseph, although of a French Canadian family, knows English, speaks it and teaches it at your school at the exclusion of all other languages, according to the wish of the Indians and the prescriptions and authorization of the Department.

Therefore the complaint of your correspondent is erroneous, false, idiotic and malicious, and without any foundation. It was made evidently with the object of creating trouble, to cast doubts and to raise prejudice. Your correspondent should be brought to proper charges so as to prevent such evidently false reports being made in the future, as they bear absence of all judgment.

Your obedient servant,

Jos. F. A. Bosse, M.D.
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant with further reference to the complaint made to you regarding the subject of education on the Restigouche Indian Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that a report on this matter has recently been received from our Indian Agent at Restigouche and he states as follows - for the last two years no instruction has been given in French at this school. The Indians did not want it and it was, therefore, not imposed on them. All instruction in the class-room is given in English, with the help of the Indian language, when necessary. The teachers employed speak English. The senior teacher speaks English only, while the assistant is a French Canadian and speaks both English and French. The text books provided are in the English language. The Indians themselves a few years ago protested against the teaching of French in this school and desired that their children be instructed in English only and this has been the language used and taught in the class-room during the past two years. The Department has no objection to the teaching of French, which was, along with English, formerly taught. The parents take very little interest in the education of their children and the attendance is very irregular.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

À Monsieur le Dr. J. F. Bosté,

Monsieur,

Le nombre toujours croissant de nos élèves nécessite nous permet de vous espérer qu'il serait urgent d'ouvrir une nouvelle classe afin de promouvoir leur avancement. L'inscription est de 115 actuellement et l'assistance est souvent au-dessus de 80; nos salles ne peuvent plus en recevoir et chaque enfant n'a pas le nombre de pieds carrés d'air prescrit par les réglements. La première classe comprend quatre divisions et la deuxième, trois, a qui donne un surcroît de travail aux institutrices.

Dans l'assurance que vous prendrez notre demande en considération et que vous aurez l'obligeance de faire les démarches nécessaires auprès du Département.

Je me dis,

Votre humble,

Si Marie de St. Joseph,
Institutrice.
Sir,

L'encouragement que les Reverends Péres Missionnaires de cette réserve, les Reverends Sœurs Institutrices et moi-même, nous efforçons de donner aux enfants sauvages de cette réserve, et le concours bienveillant du Département des Affaires des sauvages et surtout l'ouverture d'une classe de cinquième qui permet de donner un peu à deux ou trois élèves pauvres et éloignés a eu pour résultat d'augmenter considérablement l'assistance moyenne des enfants aux classes, et les quelques places d'habitués données dernièrement et que nous pouvons faire encore dans l'avenir à Jusqu'ici même le total d'inscriptions de 112, et l'assistance moyenne de 80. Ce résultat est certainement de nature à encourager les efforts commencés et montre que la voie dans laquelle nous nous sommes engagés peut être suivie avec avantage.

Il y a donc lieu de constater ce progrès et de prévoir ce qui pourrait encore s'ajouter, au tout au moins le continuer. Dans l'ordre, et en premier lieu, serait l'organisation d'une école pensionnaire, chose sur laquelle j'aimerais pouvoir de revenir avant le printemps.

Après que les Reverends Péres et les Reverends Sœurs Institutrices m'auront parlé de ce qui devrait se faire immédiatement, je les ai priés de bien vouloir me donner leurs vues par écrit et je vous envoie aujourd'hui leurs lettres demandant une troisième institutrice. Les raisons données sont, je crois, très suffisantes : deux institutrices pour 80 enfants sont certainement insuffisantes pour les raisons qu'ils vous donnent, et je ne puis que prier le Département de bien vouloir faire face à la situation en ouvrant une troisième classe et en payant le salaire d'une troisième institutrice qui sera fournie encore par la Communauté des Reverends Sœurs du St. Roseire, et que cette communauté est prête à fournir.

Il y a encore une deuxième étape de l'école : une salle inoccupée qui aurait servi à cette troisième classe; il n'y aurait pour le département qu'à fournir en plus que 10 pupitres nouvelles (20 élèves), 1 tricorne pour la maîtresse et deux tableaux noirs.

Il serait très avantageux que cette classe put s'ouvrir après la vacance de Noël, et j'ose espérer que le département donnera sans tarder son approbation à l'engagement d'une troisième maîtresse, et verra à faire parvenir le matériel nécessaire.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Agent des sauvages.

Sir:

I have visited the classes of the Indians, and I found that the attendance was much better than the past year. The Indians seem to be very much attached to the classes, they read well, and have good writing, especially among those who are most assiduous. I also noted that the classes are crowded, and there are too many divisions in the advanced classes. Would it not be possible to furnish a new class, on the second floor, which is already to be used, and to employ a third teacher. In this way more attention could be devoted to children who have too much time to play when the teacher is explaining the lessons to the children of the other divisions in the class.

The Rev. Sisters could furnish another teacher at the beginning of next year.

I am told that the number of children registered is 110, and that the average attendance is about 80. This is too many for the most advanced to get all the benefits they should receive in their classes when the teacher has to divide her time into four (4) parts.

I dare hope that you will consider this question and that you will be able to take action in the near future.

Yours, etc.

J. Placide

Sir:

The number of our Micmac pupils is constantly increasing, we take permission to express that it would be urgent to open a third class so as to help their advancement. The registration is at present one hundred and twelve (112), and the attendance is often above eighty (80). Our classes cannot receive more, and each child has not the required number of cubic feet of air prescribed by the regulations. The first class comprises four (4) divisions, and the second three (3) which gives a great deal of overwork to the teachers.

Hoping that you will kindly take our request into earnest consideration, and that you will kindly take the necessary steps with the Department, I remain

Teacher
Sir:

The devotion of the Rev. Missionary Fathers of this Reserve, that of the Rev. Teaching Sisters and myself, who are directing all our efforts to give the Indian children of this Reserve, together with the splendid help of the Department of Indian Affairs, and especially the opening of a cooking class which permits to give some dinners to the local children attending who live at a distance; this has had as result to increase the average attendance considerably of children attending classes, and a few dollars which were spent recently to clothe a few of them and which we could furnish again in the future has, until now, brought the total of names registered to 113, and the average attendance to 80. This result is certainly of such nature to encourage the efforts which have been started and shows that the policy followed can be very profitable.

It is, therefore, interesting to know this progress and to increase it or at least keep it going. The first thing to do would be to organize a boarding school, a matter on which I will have the pleasure to write again before the Spring.

As the Rev. Fathers and the Rev. Sisters have spoken to me about what should be done immediately, I requested them to kindly give me their opinion in writing, and I am enclosing herewith their letters asking for a third teacher. The reasons given, I believe, are very satisfactory; two teachers for 80 children is certainly not sufficient for the reasons which they give, and I can only beg the Department to meet the situation by opening a third class and paying the salary of a third teacher who would be furnished again by the Rev. Sisters of the St. Rosary.

There is remaining on the second floor of the school an unoccupied room which could be used for this third class; the Department would only have to furnish ten (10) double desks (30 pupils) a desk for the teacher and two blackboards.

It would be advantageous if this class could be opened after the Christmas holidays, and I dare hope the Department will give its approval to the nomination of a third teacher, and send the necessary material without delay.

Yours, etc.,

Jos. F. X. Bossé, M.D.,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM:

The present day school building at Restigouche was erected by contract in the summer of 1909. The contract price was $3875. It is a two storey building, the lower storey having two classrooms and the upper was for use as a residence for the teaching Sisters. The building is heated by a furnace. Adequate drainage facilities were provided at the time the school was built, and the drainage was thoroughly overhauled and put in good repair during the summer of 1924. The school is built on property which belongs to the Roman Catholic Church.

In December, 1922, it was necessary, owing to the increased attendance, to provide a third classroom, and one of the rooms in the teachers' residence portion was taken for this purpose. Since that time the Rev. Sisters have taken up the teaching of domestic science, and are now using the whole of this building for school purposes. The Rev. Sisters reside in the Convent near the school, and do not occupy any part of the school building for residence purposes.

A request has been received from the Superior of the Capuchin Order, at Restigouche, who are the missionaries to the Indians at that point, for a grant of $300 to make certain alterations to a part of their convent to provide residential facilities for the 3 teachers of the Indian school.

Dear Sir,

Allow me to bring to your knowledge a few reasons that urge us to ask the permission to begin school at 12.40 P.M. and close at 3.40.

All the children having their dinner here are too numerous, as you know, to be served at the same time. While the third and the fourth group are taking their dinner, the first and the second group are out of doors and they find it hard to stay out in the cold until 1 o'clock. Many poorly clad little bodies shiver from the cold while we are powerless to better their condition. Had we a gymnasium it would be easy to send them in under the direction of one teacher!.....

But, the future prepares better days, does it not?.....

It would also be very advantageous to sweep the school rooms by day light. As there are no lights in the school, it is quite dark at 4 o'clock during the winter months.
Please, suffer another request. The teacher of the Superior Class being very skillful in drawing and carpenter's work, has given the boys a fondness for that handicraft which is a marvellous means to keep them at school, as well as to develop their skill.

The boys are anxious to have their share of work to exhibit, next June, along with the girls' sewing and knitting.

For the purpose, will you please, supply us with six (6) Coping Saws, three (3) sets of twelve blades and six (6) sheets 3 ply board, about 4 x 8 ft, or allow us to buy them at Eaton's. The whole will cost about $5.00.

We shall send the Department a few samples of their work.

Awaiting a favorable answer and thanking you for past favors,

I am,
Dear and kind Sir,

Very respectfully yours,

Kind and dear Sir,

The honor of meeting you has not been conferred on me yet; nevertheless the high position you occupy is a testimony of the beautiful qualities with which you are endowed. Fully confident in your kindness and benevolence I respectfully come to ask you the favor of a "bonus" about one hundred and seventy-five ($175.00) dollars.

Allow me to sum up a few reasons that provoke such a demand:

Firstly, to help paying the expenses of "Nurse Training" I am actually engaged in, at Campbellton Hospital. Then I intend to go to St-John N.B. or to Montreal where children only are treated. That special training is for the benefit of our little Micmac children and their mothers, as we live with the prospect of a dispensary in a near future.

Secondly, our Sisters here, since over 25 years have done the work of a janitor without any salary. Do you realize the amount of work and fatigue of those sisters who light, poke up and clean the furnace, cord wood besides the sweeping of the class-rooms?

Thirdly, during the recent fire the devotedness of
the Sisters prevented greater damage and losses in the Indian School. For were it not for the watchfulness exercised by one of them, the heating furnace, the pupils' seats and desks would have been torn to pieces. Owing to a timely "stop" just a couple of pipes and a few seats were dislocated.

In fine, on the occasion of two glorious events: that of the crowning of His Majesty King George VI and that of the Golden Jubilee of our Reverend Mother Superior General. On similar occasions, the Government has already granted rewards or bonuses to some persons who distinguished themselves with some particular achievement.

Those commentaries, I agree, are somewhat superfluous; your kind heart would have accepted my petition with less details; but knowing your manifold callings I thought it proper to give you the intuition of our situation.

With every good wish for an abundance of blessings both spiritual and temporal, throughout the new year, and thanking you for past favors,

I am,

Dear and kind Sir,

Very respectfully yours,

Sister Mary of St. Leo, Principal

Do you not suppose that her small monthly salary which she would receive would not only be a help to her, but particularly a great encouragement to persist in her heroic charity? Dear Sir,

The teaching staff at the Restigouche Indian Day School has studied the previous volume of "A Teacher's Guide Book of the Activating Program," and has been greatly interested in our instructional school program. We trust that such studies will be of great benefit towards the growth of our children.

It is obvious that the Activating Program calls for far more skilled teachers than normally in a normal situation.

To avoid failure, besides possessing thorough knowledge of the materials now contained in the new instructional school, the classes should be well provided with a necessary library for pupils and guides for the teacher, which we presently are lacking.

I notice that for the preparation of a unit of work, one teacher has consulted three different libraries of the city, besides their school library. The answers we have had with success. Such investigations in our environment are not available but could be found out by an educated child. Could it not?

We feel strongly about the need to begin the study of the activating program during the fall semester.

The children who started in October are working with the new method and the change appears to be fascinating. The children seem to love school and teachers, but our experience is not long and we are not yet able to appreciate.

Truly yours,

Sister M. of the Holy Eucharist,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR THIBAULT, following his inspection of RESTIGOUCHE AGENCY - dated April 10, 1945.

I visited the school and found that nearly all children were present on that day, but the Sister in charge declared that it was exceptional, as there are many absentees at all times, for the least excuse or without excuse and no way to enforce school attendance without a truant officer.

However, the extension of the Family Allowance Act to Indians might prove to be quite a help to us, in matter of school attendance, as the parents are liable to lose the benefit of the Act if any child is not attending school regularly. The Act coming into effect only after the end of the present school year, we will not feel the reaction until next September.

A display of made-over clothing was on exhibition for my visit, when I met members of the Women's Club. I could not help congratulating them on their fine work in cutting, sewing and remodelling clothes, as well as on their knitting, crochet work and embroidery exhibits. There was also a good exhibit of the pupils' work to be seen.
Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch.

Dear Sir,

I have visited the Indian schools of Maria and Pointe-aux-Chene. I was told that the teachers and the pupils have only an hour for dinner. They finish at 12 noon and start again. Do you not think it is too short? Many pupils have to walk quite far. Believe they should have at least one hour and a half. All over the province of Quebec close finishes at 14:30 and starts a new school. It starts at nine in the morning and finishes at four in the afternoon.

I think it is important for health to have time enough for dinner.

Believe too that the close
in the cellar should be closed; it is damp.

I give you the cost of my services and expenses.

Ottawa, April 10, 1946.

MEDICAL

Mr. Isaac Caplin, Councillor, and his wife, came to the front of the hall, and Mrs. Caplin gave a very realistic demonstration of a whipping her child had received from one of the Teaching Sisters. During her talk she became very excited, waving her arms—kicking at times—and stated that the teacher had called her child "skunk, stink," etc.; she advised that as a result of this punishment the child's ears had been injured. I then asked her if she had witnessed the assault on her child, and she said "no," but that her child had informed her of the ill-treatment she had received. I asked her when this happened and she informed me that it was about five years ago, and admitted, when questioned, that the Sister who administered the punishment was no longer at the school. I told the Chief that this charge was too ridiculous to be entertained, and that it would not be possible now to investigate the complaint and satisfactorily decide whether the punishment was unjust or not.

Mrs. W.P. Martin then came forward, and in tears and a quavering voice she stated that she did not want me to come back to Ottawa and condemn and blacken the good name and character of all the Indians at Restigouche because of an unfounded charge submitted by a disgruntled Indian woman, as there
not a word of truth in Mrs. Caplin's accusations. She stated that she and her large family had all gone utmost kindness and consideration. She further stated that, as a member of the Women's Homemakers' Club she spent a great deal of her time in the school and she never saw a school child ill-treated or abused, adding that if the children attended school regularly and applied themselves, undoubtedly, they would be much brighter and more intelligent. One of Mrs. Martin's boys, about eighteen years of age, came forward and corroborated his mother's statements. Other women members of the Homemakers' Club willingly confirmed everything said by Mrs. Martin. Note, there is a school for white children on the lot immediately adjoining the Indian school property. The teachers at this school are Sisters of the same Order as those teaching in the Indian school (residing in our residence). If they are qualified and satisfactory to teach the white children the, undoubtedly, they are capable of teaching in the Indian school.

When I returned to Restigouche Indian Agent Arsenault informed me that Councillor Isaac Caplin had come to his office and complained that his little girl had been ill-treated by the teacher in the morning, and that as a result he was not going to send her to school anymore. Mr. Arsenault, being aware that this particular child had a heart condition, did not think that the teachers would ill-treat her because they had a couch in the school on which she was permitted to rest during the day. He therefore informed the Superior, Sister Euphrasia, of this charge. The Sister had a meeting of all the pupils in the class, and they stated very emphatically that the teacher had not in any way touched the child. The Superior then asked the teacher what happened, and she advised that just before lunch the child made the statement that she was not coming back to school again. I am firmly convinced that Isaac Caplin and his wife are deliberately trying to stir up resentment amongst the teachers. Complaints submitted by this couple should not be treated seriously.

X X X
J.B. Morris,
Welfare Division.

Dear Sir,

The teaching staff of the Restigouche Indian Day School humbly applied in 1945, to the Honourable Department of Indian Affairs for an increase of the salary of each of its members, from $55. to $100. a month.

Their request was judged fair, but owing to lack of funds at that time, the grant was postponed. I sincerely trust that you now stand in the position of granting—for this school year 1946—47 and subsequent ones—to both Indian Day Schools of Restigouche and Dimock Creek (Maria) Reserves, to each teacher $100.00 a month during the ten regular school months.

You are no doubt aware that the principal of each of these two schools, supervises the work of a large school-garden which the pupils cultivate. She also keeps the Sunday School meetings of the Mothers' Clubs regularly during her summer holidays, thus, never allowing herself any vacation rest. Should you not consider it just that the principal be paid on a schedule of twelve months a year?

Until now, the teachers have received their monthly payments separately as lay teachers; they have been taxed, but were entitled to the living bonus. Would you permit us to enlist the teaching Sisters of both Indian Day Schools, as religious Communities, paying them each a monthly salary of $100.00 which I consider would be sufficient to meet their expenses. I and they understand that such procedure would deprive them of the living bonus grant, and at the same time cancel the tax charges to which they and I fully agree.

Please, take this my urgent request in kind consideration, for which I would feel gratefully obliged to you.

Respectfully and cordially

Sister Mary of the Annunciation,

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY.

Inspection of Restigouche Indian Day School.

This school is somewhat crowded. There are five classrooms, two of which are rather small. The primary room has thirty-five desks but the enrolment is forty-two pupils. The second room has thirty-four single desks and an enrolment of forty pupils. The third room has seventeen double desks and an enrolment of thirty-six pupils. The fourth room has a capacity for twenty pupils but has an enrolment of twenty-eight. The fifth room which is of the same size as the fourth has an enrolment of twenty-seven. This gives us a total enrolment of one hundred and seventy-three. There are a number of children who should be attending school but are not and no pressure is exercised to make them attend due to lack of accommodation.

The teachers feel that the school should be enlarged, however, I am rather inclined to believe that a two-room school with attached teacherage would be suitable so that we could employ a male teacher to help in the education of the boys, which as we are well aware is still lacking at various places. This situation needs to be settled early in the Spring in order to come to a definite conclusion. I am satisfied that very good work is being done by the teachers at this school and I hope that on my next visit to be able to administer
a few achievement tests for the purpose of first, to give us an idea of the progress being made and second to give the teachers an insight into the method of testing.

On visiting this school the first improvement I noticed was the new sewage system, in fact, I had it connected while I was there and it seemed to function satisfactorily. The residence is still on the old system which apparently has given trouble to the school. It is rather difficult to ascertain the reason for this unless the difficulty was between the junction of the school with the residence. However, should the residence develop similar trouble as was experienced at the school, the residence sewage will have to be connected to this new system. It is difficult to understand why this was not done at the same time.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Training.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School has to solve a problem which she presently stands unable to resolve alone!

On April 1st we generally admit among our pupils the seven year old children for three months preparation which has proven a great help to them when they return in the Fall. This Spring, the Indian pupils are too numerous and attend too regularly to permit us to accept any new comers. The 1st and 2nd grade department made to accommodate 30 pupils respectively register 36 and 45 young ones with an attendance of 93% last month. Some of them sit on the blackboard platforms and kneel on the floor to write. Would you prefer turning the sewingroom into a classroom for which I could no doubt obtain a teacher or would it be better accepting all pupils of school age and give them only half a day each? To my humble opinion they would advance more by separating them in two groups than to have overcrowded classrooms.

Kindly advise me how to act in this matter if it be your desire to favour the beginners.

The enlargement of the Restigouche Indian Day School is indispensable for September if the Honourable Department of Indian Affairs wish to provide schooling to all the pupils of school age.

July 14, 1949

Mr. A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Vocational Training,
Education Division.

Dear Mr. Doucet,

I am pleased to inform you, kind Mr. Doucet, that we have presented eight pupils for the 7th Grade examinations sent by the Department of Public Instruction of the Province and all received their certificate. This statement admits them to the 9th Grade in New Brunswick. I am presently trying to place six in different High Schools. One boy, Brennie Labellois 16 years of age, would be desirous of taking a carpenter and painting course.

Would you kindly send me the address of the Montreal School where such trade is taught. I could then make the application for the said pupil myself while asking for the prospectus.

Two electricians came to make their electric-wiring estimates. They seem to be figuring about $1500.00 I guess. The approximate price per outlet is $5.00 This explains the difference between Ontario and Quebec.

Reverend Father Lucien is not giving me any hope for the land between the French and Indian School. The last I spoke to him about, he stated that he intended to annex a town hall at the end of the present school. It might change yet, as their nominations will take place in September only.

Keeping a kind remembrance of your short but worthy visit.

Most gratefully yours,

Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist...
August 8, 1949.

Mr. C. R. Nadeau,

I will be inspecting this school on September 6 or 7, when I can discuss with you other matters concerning its operation. Please do not notify the teachers of my intended inspection trip.

Bernard F. Neary,

Quebec, June 11th, 1907.

Mr. Boucher de la Briture,
Superintendent of Public Instruction,
Quebec.

Sir:

(Prestigouche School)

There were 45 pupils present on the occasion of my visit, and I distributed 10 prizes in books.

Now, the house that is used for class-rooms is not suitable for the purpose. Erected in 1865, it is quite dilapidated. It is too small for the number of pupils enrolled: each one of them has only 78 cubic feet of air, while the minimum required is 150. The system of ventilation is greatly in fault; the roof leaks all over and is only 8 feet in height between the ceiling and the floor while the law prescribes a minimum of 10 feet.

With such a large number of pupils, two classes are absolutely necessary under the direction of two teachers.

The maximum for a single teacher in a single school ought to be 50. To sum up, it may therefore be said that it is urgent that the present school-house be pulled down to make room for a building in accordance with school laws and suitable for the present needs of the school population.

I have, &c.,

Sgd. G.E. Marquis,
School Inspector.
Ottawa, July 3, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

I beg to call your attention to the remarks of Mr. Public School Inspector Marquis on the Restigouche school.

"The house that is used for class-rooms is not suitable for the purpose. Erected in 1865, it is quite dilapidated. It is too small for the number of pupils enrolled; each one of them has only 78 cubic feet of air, while the minimum required is 150. The system of ventilation is greatly in fault; the roof leaks all over and is only 8 feet in height between the ceiling and the floor, while the school law prescribes a minimum of 10 feet.

With such a large number of pupils, two classes are absolutely necessary under the direction of two teachers. The maximum for a single teacher in a primary school ought to be 50.

To sum up, it may therefore be said that it is urgent that the present school-house be pulled down to make room for a building in accordance with school laws and suitable for the present needs of the school population."

As you will see from the above extract from the Inspector's report on this school a new building is absolutely necessary. There are no funds at present available for this purpose, but I would suggest that Mr. Ogilvie be instructed to prepare a plan, specifications and estimate for a two-roomed school building, so that provision may be made in next year's estimates for its being built.

Sir,

The divers correspondences concerning the repairs to be done on the schoolhouse I beg to say that I have got an expert on the matter to examine what would likely cost to make the house habitable for the winter. After a thorough examination he states as follows: "The roof has to be made a new, the lower part of the wall is very rotten I can break a part of it with my finger there appear to be nothing holding the sleeper specially at the east end, the floor is heading down, the base board, the corner cut and a part, at least, of the windows has to be renewed, in fact, one can tell what will really be renewed until he commences to work. It will certainly cost £2 or £300.00 and yet it will last long. The building don't matter while it is repaired, it will soon tumble down."

When asked him would be the probable cost of a new one, he said that a good house to suit the purpose could be built for between £150.00 and £180.00.

Restigouche, July 6, 1908.

Mr. Jeremie Pitre,
Pointe la Garde,
Que.

Dear Sir,

I have learned that you propose to have important repairs made to the school-house. This is not without necessity. However, I am not disposed to be very much pleased about this; I should very much prefer that you should do what must be done sooner or later—that you should rebuild. You will recollect that the Superintendent of Public Instruction condemned the school last year, not directly because it was in need of repairs, but because the building itself did not comply with the school regulations. And I believe that he would have insisted, if he had not thought that with the Hon. the present Minister of Indian Affairs a first warning would be sufficient. As for myself, I will tell you frankly that when the Government gave such a good example of progress (of which our white commissioners were much in need) in improving so considerably the treatment of its school mistresses, I am very much astonished that it remains, I was going to say, behind in the matter of building. Not only have the schools at Sandy Hill and Oak Bay been improved, but there is being built at present for the whites, not far from the old Government buildings, a wholly new school, spacious and (by comparison) magnificent. Several Indians have seemed to be annoyed at thus being passed over at their place; perhaps they would have shown this discontent if you had said more plainly that their Department wants
to repair instead of to build.

I am quite certain that if Mr. J.C. Scott, who is so zealous about schools, would spend only two or three days here, looking and listening, he would feel keenly the comparison that I suggest and would act without delay in getting the Department to take the place again that it is going to lose here if it is satisfied with costly and temporary repairs.

Perhaps they are waiting to do better! However, we cannot wait much longer.

I remain with respect

Your, &c.,

F. Pacifique,
missionary.

Sir,

Permit me in my capacity as inspector visiting this school to ask you to look over my reports on this subject of June, 1907, and April, 1908, before coming to a decision.

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said work, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

Sir,

On the 25th ultimo I carefully examined the school site on the St Anne de Restigouche reserve. Work was actively proceeding on the building.

The foundation stone, about which complaints have been made is flat free stone, thin but of good dimensions. So far as I can see it is free from objection and from the opinions gathered this was adopted as my opinion without obtaining an expert to examine it. The supercies of most of the stone is such that it will itself form a bond for the foundations. In conversation with the working masons I was told that it made a splendid foundation but the expenses of the contractor would be increased by the amount of mortar required.

The foreman in charge of building required immediate instruction regarding drainage. The choice lay between making a new drain to the river bank some three or four hundred feet and connecting with an adjacent and satisfactory at a distance of twenty or thirty feet. As there

J.D. McLean, Esq.
Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
seemed to be no objection to the short connection unless such were raised by the Sister Superior of the nuns who occupy the residence which closely adjoins the school building. She was seen at my request by Mr. Patric and said the connection might be made. The foreman was consequently so instructed and was told that he might go on with the work leaving it to the Department and the contractor to determine whether the cost was included in the building contracts or not.

The area of the selected lot is small and will not afford room for the gardening that it has been proposed to instruct pupils in. There is, however, a good playground between the building and the road and the site is a nice one.

Some little objection was heard to the building being placed on property which belongs to the Roman Catholic church instead of on the Indian reserve. Father Pacifique, Superior of the mission, says as to this that as the building is upon a lot which has been so long used for school purposes the Bishop of the diocese could not well object to continuance of such use even if so disposed. But objection would hardly arise from this source as the mission is gaining a valuable building intended in part for school purposes and in part as a residence for the reverend sisters who control the teaching and a practical future control of the education of children on
the reserve. But if at any time it is desired to put
the teaching into other hands or to secure the residence
for a lay teacher objections might come from other sources.

The lot has nice shade trees upon it and the position

Specification
of Furnace work for Residences
Indian Bay School, Que.

Furnaces.—
Provide and fix up in convenient position near smoke flues and where directed a warm air, coal or wood furnace of approved Canadian manufacture, with all appurtenances complete.

The furnace to be fitted with heavy cast iron casing or bricked in, according to type of furnace selected, and to be provided with cast iron vapor pan, dust louver, heat exchanger, etc., and all necessary wall pipes, cold air pipe, main pipe, wall and floor registers, etc., as required to fully heat the two dining rooms on ground floor and the three and living rooms on floor above.

Pipes.—
The warm air pipes to be of sufficient capacity to conduct the required amount of air to the room to be heated and are to be made formed of the best L.O. charcoal tin, covered with asbestos paper.

Smoke pipe.—
The smoke pipe to be of heavy galvanized iron of sufficient capacity to provide ample combustion for furnaces.

Registers.—
All registers used to have borders and to be of Buttle and Daily pattern, japanned.
Foul air faces.—
The foul air faces shown showing in class rooms to be twenty by thirty inches.

Cold air shaker-duct.—
Supply and fix cold air duct having enamelled iron equal to the combined area of all hot air ducts and connect the same with furnaces. Provide also a check and regulation attachment for operating cold air as well furnaces from ground floor.
Provide also the necessary connection to ventilation flue as shown under basement stairway for left hand class room.

Galvanised Iron Work.—
The cold air duct and foul air connection to flue to be of twenty eight gauge galvanised iron.

Guarantee.—
A written guarantee must be given to successfully heat the building to a temperature of seventy degrees when the weather is at twenty degrees below zero.

Materials.—
All of the materials to be of the best quality and the work finished in a first class manner and to the entire satisfaction of the Inspector.

Napier stated that he had without hesitation handed him over the £50 granted for this purpose. In his letter Col. Napier recommended the appointment of a teacher at a salary of £50 per annum.

On the 15th Dec. 1835 and on 15th Oct. 1836 Col. Napier enclosed letters from the Missionary and from Wm. Gent. Cazier asking for assistance toward establishment of a school at Restigouche. In reply to these letters Col. Napier was informed that so soon as he was able to certify that the school was in operation under a teacher approved by the Dept., that a grant of £50 would be made with the understanding that this was not to be an annual grant.

On the 14th April 1837 Col. Napier enclosed a report.

Ottawa, December 13th, 1932.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your Vouchers Nos. 182 and 184, amounting in all to $80.00, for midday meal supplies at the Restigouche Indian Day School, also your Voucher No. 183, for $20.00, for sewing material supplied to this school. The Department has, apparently, given no authority for these expenditures. It has been decided, however, to pay the accounts, but I would point out that unauthorized expenditures will not be paid for in future.

Our funds this year are extremely limited and while, last year, an allowance of $20 a month was made for midday meal supplies, the Department finds it necessary to reduce the expenditure this year. You should, therefore, confer with the teacher and arrange to discontinue supplying a number of articles so as to reduce the total cost. In addition, the midday meal should not be supplied after the end of April. Before incurring any further expenditure for this purpose, you should advise the Department what reduction the Principal of the school and yourself consider can be made in the cost of the midday meal supplies for the months of January, February, March and April.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

But I am really sorry that the Department refuses to buy any more serving materials.

Being in charge of this school for the past twenty-three years, I am in position to certify that a midday meal and teaching of domestic science are the two agents which have helped us to secure the fine attendance we presently notice. This winter we sometimes number over hundred children in our classes.

Cooking and serving greatly interest both parents and children; attract the girls and draw them to prolong their school years. Previously no children above 2 years old were seen in our classrooms, while this year we have boys of 15 years and girls of 16 and 17 years. In fact, I can assure that the
teaching of domestic science is very successful in this school, as acknowledged by school inspectors and all authorized visitors.

So, the Department would greatly oblige us by giving us the authorization to purchase school materials for at least $5 more, making this a reduction of $5 on the annual grant of $50 allowed us in March 1881.

Hoping that my humble request will be favored with a generous compliance, I beg the Department to accept in advance my sincerest thanks.

Respectfully yours,

Sr. M. of St. Joseph

Madam:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the grant provided for the purchase of supplies for the pupils' midday meal at the Restigouche Indian Day School, and also regarding the grant allowed for the purchase of sewing material.

In reply I have to say that, after giving the matter full consideration, it has been decided to allow a grant at the rate of $15 per month in the purchase of supplies for the pupils' midday lunch for the period from January 1st, next, to the end of April, 1933. It is considered that the serving of the lunch during the winter months will be sufficient. It is noted that you can have the children bring their own bread, and this would help in the cost of the other supplies.

Regarding a grant for the purchase of material for the sewing classes, I have to say that the Department will allow the sum of $35 for the present school year for this purpose. Our funds this year have been so considerably reduced that it is regretted the above amounts for the purchase of supplies for the midday lunch and for the sewing classes are all the Department is able to authorize. I am sure you will join with the Department in endeavouring to keep all expenses as low as possible.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, May 16, 1933.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the communication which you forwarded, from the Principal of the Restigouche Indian Day School, requesting that a grant of $20 be provided to purchase prizes for the pupils, to be awarded before the school closes for the coming summer holidays.

In reply I have to say that, as our funds this year have been so considerably reduced, it will not be possible to allow a grant at the present time to any of our Indian day schools to purchase prizes. I regret, therefore, that the request of the Rev. Sister cannot be granted.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. Richard, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
